reviewText:
TL;DR: I have hundreds of hours on the Magic Duels series and Hearthstone - I uninstalled both shortly after discovering HEX and haven't looked back.  It's free - try it!

HEX is a digital trading card game done right, embracing digital mechanics and having robust tournament support.  PvE modes are fun, rewarding, and accessible, but expect a significant grind to play PvP as a F2Player.

Highs:
- Magic the Gathering (MTG) players already know the rules
- Unlike MTG's digital offerings, HEX embraces mechanics that are only possible with digital cards
- Unlike Hearthstone, HEX is a complex game with considerable interaction between players
- Robust tournament support, including synchronous Limited that fires regularly (<hourly) and asynchronous Sealed
- The RPG campaign is unlike anything I've played before (working on my 6th clear atm...)
- Best community I've ever seen!
- Devs clearly love the game and have a number of awesome features in the works
- All cards (and other items/currency) are easily tradable to other players

Lows:
- Auction house is tedious to use - I tend to stick to trade chat" transactions
- Takes about 10h to grind a draft entry fee as a beginner - I'd recommend spending $10 on drafts to jump-start your collection and speed up the grind"

reviewText:
I am a streamer who has played TCGs for over 10 years including MtG, Hearthstone and HEX since alpha. Here's what you need to know about this game:
[Along with a TLDR answer for each question]

1.) What is Free to Play in this game?
[Many hours of PvE]
PvE is RPG-meets-TCG content that allows you to have fun, learn the game and farm cards and in-game currency at a decent rate. You can also play the auction house, and tournaments will start paying for themselves once you are good enough. A small investment goes a long way to make the grind more enjoyable.

2.) So how much do I end up paying in the end?
[From $0 to $1,000 and beyond]
You can enjoy the majority of the game by grinding and trading for what you need. But if you want to compete at the highest level of tournaments, like the $100k invitational, a large collection will be a long-term advantage. It may cost you a lot, but it will gain value over time and can be resold!

3.) Is this like Magic: The Gathering?
[Similar concept with different strengths]
HEX has a great online experience, uses its digital nature to innovate, has a growing RPG PvE and is easier/cheaper to get into, but it's not as vast as MtG yet and lacks its face-to-face social interaction.

4.) Does this have a good community?
[One of the best around]
It's easily among the most helpful and generous I've encountered, and the streamers are fantastic. The official forums and fan-sites are informative and active with guides and great tournaments.

5.) Can I trust the developer?
[Yes!]
The company is designing their own dream game. That is why this is a AAA quality game, despite coming from a still growing Indie studio. This sustainable perfectionism can lead to longer wait times, but they are worth it in the end.

6.) Should I play this game?
[If you are looking for a long-term game, yes!]
This is not an instant gratification game that presses your reward center a couple of times and then leaves you wanting. TCGs are one of the most rewarding genres you can get into, allowing you to grow your skill and collection over decades with flexible time and money commitment. You wont regret giving this a try.

reviewText:
Feature Review
What is Hex?
Hex is a Trading Card Game (TCG), not unlike things we've seen before.

What makes it different?
Hex was originally marketed as an MMO/Card game, and while it's not there yet, it is becoming one with each major content drop.

What do you mean MMO/Card game?
Well, for your PvE experience you will pick a race and a class. You are given a deck containing basic cards, and then you are encouraged to go explore the adventure zone(s) to collect cards and equipment; or you can improve your skills against players and try to be among the best.

Equipment?
Yes, Hex has equipment for your character, equipment that change what cards do, when you can play them, or what they cost.
The equipment is specific to your cards, so you pick and choose what equipment you want for the deck you are currently playing.

Then we go explore?
Correct, when you get into the game you can choose to run the capmpaign, the arena (PvE) or any of the many variants of PvP available.

PvE?
The campaign, has dungeons to be beaten, and loot to be found. You level your character, pick your talents, and upgrade your deck.
In the Frostring Arena, you are faced up against a list of 20 opponents with a single deck, and three lives, changing bosses and a hidden random encounter keeps it very fun, and rewarding.

PvP?
There are several ways of playing against other players:
Sealed deck
Draft
Constructed

Sealed and constructed can both be played as a live tournament, or as a gauntlet tournament where you can play until you have 5 wins, or three losses, and in both then you get rewarded according to how well you did.

And, all this is free?
Well, the game has two different currencies, platinum and gold.
You can acquire gold from the PvE experience, or by selling cards, chests, packs, mercenaries or equipment on the auction house
With platinum, you can buy packs, starter decks, and entry to tournaments, and is obtained by purchasing it from the store, or by selling your above mentioned items.
Depending on what you want out of the game, it can cost you money, but you can certainly try it and enjoy it at no cost at all.

Is it worth my time and money?
That's really hard for me to say, but as for time, it is certainly worth mine. Concerning your money, it's not like you need to throw down anything to give it a try, so I would say yes on both accounts.

To sum up, PvE is free, and you are rewarded with cards (both PvE and PvP) as well as equipment, and dust to upgrade the art on the cards to extended art, all of which can be sold to other players for gold or platinum.
You can play against players, and if you are good, and hardcore enough to attempt it, you can try and compete in tournaments for good prizes.

Card packs contain a single rare or legendary card, a few uncommons, and quite a few commons up to a total of 17 cards, when buying or winning packs, there is a chance that it will generate a PRIMAL PACK that will contain 2 legendaries, and 13 rares.

You can construct as many decks as you would like, with as many colours and cards as you want. And you get to pick the champion yourself, there are quite a few, and only more coming.

The game is very promising, the digital-only design space opens up some very interesting mechanics, from as generating new cards, or shuffling cards into your opponents deck, to permanent buffs and cards with sockets.
Content is being released at a rather slow rate at the moment, so if you join early, you have a good chance at catching up.

Tournaments are run weekly, and there are monthly VIP tournaments that reward alternate art cards worth upwards of 15$ each, and the entry fee is much less, but you do need to have the VIP entry tickets.

The game comes with a tutorial, and the community is very helpful.

It may seem overwhelming at first, but start by jumping into the ever expanding campaign, and venture into the world of PvP once you feel like you are ready.

I have played the game since alpha and even now, the special encounters, and race/class rewards in the campaign keeps you coming back for more.

reviewText:
HEX - The best digital TCG you will ever play.

Why?

Player-to-Player trade for all items in the game, with easy ways to sell cards third party.
This alone makes it better than games like Hearthstone, Faeria, Duelyst, etc. where you are locked to cards you own. Being able to build assets for the time you invest in the game makes this game one of the best values for your luxury time.

PvE!!!!!!!!!! and endless deck building possibilities through equipment!
The AI for HEX is awesome, and keeps getting better. The RPG elements and leveling system offer a lot of variety, and deck building options with PvE exclusive cards and equipment will offer endless replayability! The content release plan is said to have 7 years of content currently planned, with 2-3 anticipated large PvE content and progression patches per year. The experience is extremely unique for a TCG, and will eventually have co-op MMO style modes added.

PvP is outstanding and the constructed and limited format scene are developing nicely with each new set.
There is a draft format, sealed format, and constructed format where packs are rewarded as prizes. Including some free community tournaments as well, where packs and plat are rewarded as prizes. Unlike other popular card games now, part of the cost of limited formats, like draft and sealed, is in the packs, which you keep all contents of after the tournament. The constructed format has a rich meta that has evolved with time, and will get better with each set release.

Marketing Model knowledge is an important step to appreciating the value HEX provides.
Whether it be Primal Packs(and you will love these babies), Chase cards, Exclusive events, Hitting an amazing chest spin, or trading your gold for plat to remain a free-to-play player, there are a ton of intricate pieces that tie into the Marketing Model for HEX, that really reward you for your understanding. At the end of the day, 1 simple rule applies - Time = Money, but if you put in a little bit of Money to jump-start your experience, it can save you a ton of time grinding early on. If you want to be a virtually free-to-play player, with it comes an understanding to build a strong PvE deck, and having the time to farm gold, and then convert gold and cards on the AH to continue playing all modes for free. F2P is definitely something that can be done, and the better understanding you have, and the more time-invested, the easier it will be for you, as a player, to casually drop 1400 plat in a day to play paid limited tournaments, and convert those rewards.

Future Development, and other bells and whistles.
There are a lot more formats, PvE content, RPG experience, MMO experience, cards, equipment, exclusive events to come. This game is seriously a black-hole of replayability, and for that, I both love it and hate it, as it's hard for me to put the same value into other games, and I find myself spending more and more time playing HEX for both the value and fun experimenting with endless options.

What is HEX up against? - Genre competition - Scope?
Faeria / Hearthstone / Duelyst / Duel of Champions - Fast and fun games, but all CCG's - you can't trade, and they have poor AI and poor PvE modes. 100% limited to cards for customization. Dumb-downed mechanics.

Magic the gathering - This is grandpa's TCG, that refuses to iterate for the digital age. The digital nature of HEX is constantly being pushed, with permanent buffs, and sockets, etc. Things MTG never could do. The price point is twice as much, and your time does not feel as valued. Their PvE titles leave a lot to be desired, and they don't have a cool equipment system.

Play HEX! You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Tl;dr - I play mtg, hearthstone, etc. and Hex is my favorite by far; you should absolutely give it a chance

If you love MtG but hate MtG:O, or if you love TCGs in general, this is a game you should absolutely look at.
I have been following the development of this game since the Kickstarter was announced and am thrilled to finally see it coming to Steam.

This game combines my love of having a valuable card collection, trading and following the market with my love of not spending much money (packs are below half the price of MtG boosters) and optional free/f2p ways to play/collect.

This game delivers on all fronts with an intuitive auction house and in-game economy, competitive drafting and tourney support, and great immersive PvE campaign content that is still being expanded. The PvE content gains you rewards in the form of PvE cards + packs as well as valuable equipment to augment your cards, and gold (the ingame currency) all of which can be used to trade for PvP packs and cards on the auction house which would normally cost a small amount of money.

The community is great, the developers are great, and above all the game is great.  In addition to all that, the current content is only a small fraction of what is set to come in to future (think guilds, co-op dungeons and raids, even more MMO aspects, etc.). While the game isn't completely where it wants to be yet in terms of projected content, if you're willing to be patient it has huge potential.

Definitely give this one a try!

reviewText:
(Although my Steam hours have just started, I've been playing HEX since Alpha for many many hours)

There isn't much I can say, which hasn't already been said. So in my review I will focus on a very specific demographic.

Hi there, long time Magic: The Gathering players! The answer to your question is a massive YES.

YES, this is that game you've been waiting for all this time. Frustrated about the fact that Wizards of the Coast is apparently stuck in 2002 (looking at you MTG Online) and you see all these shiny new digital TCG/CCG coming out? You've been looking at your humongous collection of cards neatly stacked away in a closet. And you nostalgically think about the times you used to play MTG for days with your friends. Friends who have since moved far away and don't have time to get together for this anymore. It's 2016 now, surely there could be some way of reliving the joy of MTG digitally?

Well, it's time to rip apart that Chaos Orb! HEX is here and it will give you everything you've been waiting for and so much more! And that, my friend, is a promise. It's MTG, but with all the nice things you can only do in a digital environment.

I've read people complain about the fact that PVP isn't free-to-play. Well, we, as long time MTG players laugh about this. Haha! The amount of money we spend over the years on buying booster packs and single cards will never come close to what HEX costs in a long long time. ;) But I think this is one of the things I really like about HEX. Why?

No, it isn't F2P if you really want to get competitive into the PVP side of things (but PVE is totally free). But that's also why HEX is a Trading Card Game. That T actually makes a huge difference in comparison to other digital cardgames (one with Murlocs for example). You can buy, sell and trade single cards in HEX. Just like you can with MTG. There is an actual auction house and there are third party store websites, which buy and sell singles. So, yeah, you can buy that booster pack for $1.50 and pull out a Vampire King, which is currently valued at $30. You can then sell that Vampire King and buy yourself a stack of boosters or a couple of other singles you want. The money I spend in-game is actually more of an investment. And not a bottomless pit even Harrison Jones wouldn't dare to venture down in...

So, bottom line, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone looking for the best digital TCG currently on the market. Look no further, it's HEX. And if you look at the things these guys have in store for us in the future, this is only going to get better and better. See you in game!

reviewText:
I only picked this game up a week or so before it hit Steam, but I figure I've played enough to give my impressions as a newbie to the game. Since I've only been doing single player activities, I'm not going to talk a lot about the PvP aspect of the game (which has very little in common with the single player stuff, save the cards you use). Read this with that in mind.

I tried to type up something long winded, but it felt awfully pretentious and had tons of pointless information. So I'm going to condense it down into the good and the bad for ease of reading. (It's still a bit lengthy though. Sorry.)

The good:

- A good single player experience through the campaign. While hard to do, it can be beaten with your starting out collection, and you can earn gold, cards and equipment for free. It's done RPG style with quests, and there are dungeons that boast some very dangerous boss opponents. Think of it sort of like the Hearthstone adventures, but f2p and with replayability (you get cards and gold every time as opposed to just the first time you win). Having access to 8 different races and currently 3 classes is a nice touch as well, as it gives you lots of options to cater to your preferred style of play.

- The card game can accurately represent what it is like to be caught unprepared by a throng of hungry piranhas. (It's painful, yet mercifully brief, in case you wondered)

- The game has a good level of visual polish. Good artwork, little sound effects to go with every card that's played

- Another good single player experience in the arena. You're using the heroes you'd be using in PvP games here, so it's much harder to win the harder difficulty tiers. But you can grind gold here at a decent clip, and there's enough variety in opponents that it won't feel like the same thing evey time.

- It's a TCG. You can actually buy from/trade with other members of the community for packs and cards, even with the f2p earnable currency. You can also buy the premium currency from other players, again using the f2p currency

- If you can get a deck that performs consistently well in the arena, you can make it a true f2p experience as you'll be able to grind gold efficiently and start to work on the pricier aspects of the game. It will take some time and probably the shameless copying of someone else's deck list to get here, but it can be done.

-If you choose to drop $$$ on the game, you can buy the cards on an individual basis and make a strong, effective deck without spending a fortune on packs (though some cards, naturally, are super expensive anyway. But that's the nature of a TCG)

- The community so far has seemed pretty helpful in-game. It's easy to get some quick advice if you're stuck with something, most of the time.

The bad:

- Entering tournaments asks you to fork over premium money, and sometimes a few card packs as an entry fee. If you do well you'll make your entry fee back and then some, but I find the lack of a f2p, prize-less option a bit dissappointing

- You can't buy packs with the f2p currency from the game's store. You *can* buy them from other players that are selling them on the auction house, but obviously the price won't always be consistent.

- The deck builder doesn't feel incredibly intuitive. There's no way to filter out stuff you already own, and it's not possible to search for cards of a specific costing or shard threshold. This makes it very awkward to try and work out what cards you'd like to work towards getting to go with the cards already in your deck. You can mitigate it somewhat if you're looking for specific keywords, but overall it feels like it could use some improvement.

- The resource system can lead to the good old problem of mana screw/mana flood. I personally don't mind it, but I know it's a big turnoff for some people.


The verdict:

Overall the game is very similar to MTG, but it has enough uniqueness to offset the familiarity. The PvP segment of the game seems difficult to get anywhere with unless you're prepared to grind for it or drop cash on the game, but it seems the developers actually care about providing a good single player experience (which is rare in card games) and I hear an extension to the campaign mode is in the pipeline somewhere.

Give the game a shot, see what you think. If you like card based gameplay, I think this one can easily scratch that itch and at least provide a few hours of gameplay, even if you're unwilling to pay or grind. And who knows, you may find you really like it. I did, and I wasn't really expecting much when I first loaded it up.

reviewText:
Basically this is Magic the Gathering Online done right with an added free PVE campaign.

I've been playing MtG for a long time, and have fond memories of the Shandalar PC game (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magic:_The_Gathering_(1997_video_game)). So when the Kickstarter talked about dungeons and a PVE campaign, I was in.

Hex does a lot of things right: accessible PVE campaign with an easy way to grind (PVE) cards, a well-done game UI, crazy-fun cards (its digital nature allows Hex to go for more wacky things than MtG which has to work as a paper game), a working free player / paying player economy and excellent cheap (compared to MtGO) drafts.

The community is awesome, check out the Hex Twitch streams if you haven't, I regret following them way too late. Who doesn't like giveaways?

Don't play this if you expect to compete in high level PVP and don't plan to spend money. You will most likely have to invest some $$$ to start playing competitive PVP unless you really like grinding.

There are still some Kickstarter promises that haven't been delivered on. But Hex has steadily released new features and content. I expect them to keep doing so; and hope for an increased pace.

reviewText:
I'm a Twitch streamer. Hex has been my main game to stream for over two years, and I would not cast a game for that long that I didn't personally enjoy. However, Hex may not be for everyone. Read on, and let's see if the game is something you'd be interested in.

If you are looking for a card game, where the primary focus on the game are rich and strategic interactions between cards, Hex might be a game for you. Especially if you enjoy deckbuilding and brewing. With over 1300 cards available and all sorts of effects and synergies spanning all its modes, there is already many cards to take in and explore. Though, if discovering cards and deckbuilding sounds like a chore, perhaps it isn't for you.

If you enjoy card games, and like to compete against other players, Hex might be a game for you. The PvP is modeled like many competitive Trading Card Games in its tabletop roots. A small entry fee and some luck and skill can turn into awesome prizes. And at the highest level of play? Perhaps you'll win a qualifier and play in an Invitational tournament in front of an audience for a large cash prize! But if you don't like PvP play, this won't be a compelling reason for you.

On the other end of the spectrum, if you don't like the pressure of competing against other players, and just want to play out your amazing combo, Hex also has you covered. Its single player PvE play, in the form of a RPG-inspired campaign to explore and grow your own champions (that will be expanded upon in the coming years!) and an Arena mode to take on a gauntlet with a fully-geared deck. An experienced player should find about 10 hours for a single once-through playthrough. Cards, equipment, gold, loot to gain, and this is all free! But some aren't interested in single-player modes, if that is you, then feel free to ignore this section.

Do you like collecting stuff? Does the prospect of turning extra things into stuff you want sound compelling? The T in TCG stands for Trading, and Hex prides itself on its economy. The terrible feeling of getting an extra of an amazing thing, and being unable to trade it, is not in this game. Open a legendary in a pack, get a rare dungeon drop, or receive an exclusive promo in an event... and find someone who wants it in the Hex Auction House. Turn your extras, tournament winnings, farmed gold or bought platinum into anything you can find a buy or trade for. Though, if economy is not your thing, then it's not.

Well, there's a bunch of reasons I have for liking Hex. If you've read through, and one or more of those reasons intrigue you, give Hex a try. It's free to make an account, the campaign and PvE is free and you get stuff, random PVP games are free, and you have full ability to buy packs of cards if that's the kind of TCG player you are.

Hex has given me over 2 years of fun, and will likely continue to. And if you're like me, you'll like Hex too.

Disclaimer: I've been playing this game 18 months.

First off, if you are coming into Hex expecting a 100% free AAA game that gives you everything you could ever want in life and doesn't ask a thing in return... You will be sorely disappointed. F2P, especially in an environment with a living, breathing economy (i.e. TCGs, MMOs), means eventually you will either be spending some time grinding to get the things you desire, or spending money to acquire them. This is not a bad thing. A lot of people put in a lot of work to make this. They have needs (i.e. food, shelter, clothing) which cost money. If they just give away all their things, then they don't get money. No money = no basic necessities = dead developers = dead game.

For people with a realistic view of the world and a rational mind:

There are many aspects to this game. I'll start with the one that drew me in first: PVP. You see, in the early days of Hex, there was no PVE campaign. There wasn't an Arena. There was only PVP. Just to be clear I don't mean, like, the Alpha days (I was not around for that, though I've heard the stories and I admire the brave souls who made it through to Beta). I came across a Beta key just a few months prior to the release of Set 2. I had read a bit about the game some months before, so I had an idea what I was getting myself into. I had played TCG's before (several years of MtG on and off again since the mid 90's, several years of Yu-Gi-Oh more recently) and understood that this game would require some investment. At that time, in fact, there was no way to play without spending money. But I am a draft addict. And I don't mind paying companies for their hard work so long as I am satisfied with the result. And ohhhh.... was I satisfied.

I drafted my way into a fairly decent sized collection of cards when the unthinkable happened - Set 2 released! I now had another 300 cards to collect and mash into random decks. I drafted and drafted some more, and in time I had near complete playsets of both Set 1 and 2. However, things at work had gotten complicated, life did it's lifey things, and I put the game aside for several months.

Coming back 7 months later saw many changes. First, a new set had arrived. A new set, and a new challenge in both drafting and collecting all the cards I could get my grubby average sized hands on. Secondly, and more alarming, the Frost Arena had popped up out of nowhere to tempt me with its F2P design and PvE loot. I tried it a bit (and still do dabble to this day) but for the most part I went full force into draft. And over the last several months managed to collect not only a complete playset of Set 3, but also round out my first to sets for PVP playset completion :D

You might ask: So what do you do now that you've drafted all the cards?" I might (and will) answer: "I continue to draft." Not at the same 'gotta catch em all' pace as before

reviewText:
I just got into Magic The Gathering, so I decided to also give this game a shot. I am happy to report my experience so far has been great. The game does have a grind that you do need to get through before you can start to enjoy drafts with other people, but I'm looking forward to trying them when I get the chance. However, here are my pros and cons with the game.

Pros:
- Game does an alright job of teaching you the basics through a single player campaign.
- Community through the in-game chat and on their forums are generally very friendly and helpful.
- You don't need to pay real money to play, but you can if you want to accelerate your progress.
- Deviates from the gameplay of MTG just enough that it isn't an exact copy and actually betters Magic Duels in some aspects.
- Auction House so you can sell your cards to other players to buy others that you may need to build an ideal deck.
- Tournaments running all of the time, so you always have something to do, provided you have the in-game currency for it.
- Cool character system found in the campaign that allows you to give your character different abilities and perks as you level him/her up.

Cons:
- Some server issues, but these can be overlooked, as they are a common side affect of releasing on steam to a brand new audience of people.
- Developer could do a better job of notifying people if there is a problem, such as on the main menu instead of on their forums, it would help the noobs that are lazy find out what is going on.
- HUD could be worked on a tad to make it more user-friendly for people that have not touched a TCG before, or have only touched one such as hearthstone. Don't make it like hearthstone where it's blatently obvious. I don't think the majority of users will like that haha.

All in all, this is a great TCG with a thriving community, and could get even better with a bit more work and care put into it. Also, a note to anyone bashing the game, it's just been released on steam to a new audience. Give it a week or two to be able to iron out any problems related to the servers. It is definitely worth a try as there is no price of admission, and who knows.... you may just find a brand new game to sink time into.

reviewText:
I used to play physical Magic the Gathering, but as I grew older, my friends stopped playing and finding people near me became difficult. And let's be honest, MtG online or the Duel versions are complete disasters.

Hex aims to fix that problem with online TCGs. It takes a lot from MtG and makes a true modern online digital trading card game. This is NOT Hearthstone and it will never be like it. In fact, this is what Magic the Gathering should have been online, but never was.

This is currently the best online TCG with an entirely free RPG campaign, full of dungeons and with character customization (hero choice, talents...). PvP is well balanced with the meta shifting often, especially when a new set is released.

With that said, be aware that being competitive in PvP WILL require money just like any TCG if you are not a good trader. Even if you can indeed farm gold in PvE and buy some cards from other players using that gold, the majority of top tiers cards will require Platinum (unless you are lucky and someone does sell it for gold). On the other hand, PvE is and always will be completely free.

As an example, I will give you my personal experience. I invested 10$ (1000 platinum) two years ago and my cards collection is now worth 80k platinum or ~6.5M Gold. That's about 800$ worth of cards I acquired through gold farming and smart trading on the auction house.

As a final note, I'd like to mention this game has one of the nicest online communities I have ever been part of.

If you like card games, you absolutely must try it at least once !

reviewText:
I'm a veteran trading card game player and this review is primarily addressed to players already familiar with classic paper trading card games.

If you want a digital trading card game that retains the complexity of classic trading card games then HEX is for you.
Everything except card sleeves is tradable within the game which means that everything in your collection has a real world value. The game offers a great ruleset that allows a huge set of interactions, veteran card players are going to feel at home with familiar concepts like The Chain (The Chain in WoW TCG, The Stack in MTG), activated abilities, triggered abilities, combat and resource systems similar to MTG, and a lot of other things. HEX also innovates a lot in the digital space; modifiers on cards can be tracked throughout different zones (even in zones hidden for players, like your deck), cards can interact with zones without revealing/shuffling/searching or other shenanigans, effects allowing you to see cards in your opponents hand without them knowing, transforming cards into other cards, etc. etc.
The game offers a great PVP experience with both constructed and limited formats (draft, sealed), and as in classic trading card games, you get to keep all cards and packs obtained in these game modes which justifies the small entry fee. There is also a PVE part of the game that is completely free to play, at the moment this includes a campaign with character progression, talent tree, dungeons, quests, equipment, and card rewards.
HEX has a superb economy with two different currencies: Platinum and Gold. Platinum is bought with real world money, while Gold is given as a reward in PVE. Entries to PVP tournaments has a small Platinum fee, but opening packs yields Chests which in turn needs Gold. This results in paying players needing Gold, and since everything is tradable the paying players lists cards and items on the Auction House for Gold, hence everything in the game can be obtained by just playing for free (however there is a lot of grinding involved to get the most expensive cards).

All in all, HEX is a great game with a great future! Give it a try!

reviewText:
tl;dr: Whether you're a F2P player or a paying customer, if you like trading card games, Hex is absolutely worth your time.

I've been playing Hex for a bit over two years now. Hex is without a doubt the best digital trading card game, as long as you're willing to invest a bit of your time or money (or better, both).

Business Model - Something that can be confusing for new players is the way Hex merges a very fair F2P model for the PVE campaign with a very standard P2P model for PVP. You can play as much of the campaign as you want, completely free of charge, and you will never feel pressured to put money into the game. The campaign throws free cards at you left and right, as well as a currency called Gold. Gold can be used to buy PvP cards from the auction house, but you can also just straight up trade it with other players for Platinum (the paid currency). In this way, it is possible for a completely free player to compete and win huge prizes without ever spending a dime. In fact, the recent winner of the $40,000 top prize at the 2016 Hex Invitational was one such player.

That said, the amount of grinding required to cobble together a serious constructed PvP deck is staggering, and I wouldn't recommend doing so to most people. If you want to PvP in Hex, expect to spend money (Hex costs about 30-40% as much as Magic).

On the PvP side, Hex offers TCG staples like Constructed and Draft tournaments, as well as an innovative asynchronous Gauntlet mode that lets you spread out a tournament over as much time as you'd like, playing a match here and there when you have time. PvP tournaments reward valuable prizes for doing well, so if you polish your skills (and are willing to sell cards on the auction house) it's very possible to go infinite and keep playing indefinitely on a small, fixed initial investment.

Now that the ugly money talk is out of the way, let's look at some of the pros and cons:

The Good:
- The Hex community is, bar-none, the best community for any online game I've ever played. Everyone is extremely friendly, helpful, and generous. New players frequently find themselves showered with free common and uncommon cards to help jumpstart their collections. In my opinion, the best place to interface with the Hex community is on Twitch[twitch.tv]. There are tons of great streamers, and you usually can't go wrong by just picking whoever has the most viewers at the moment. Watching streams is a great way to learn about the game, and both streamers and other viewers are generally thrilled to answer a new player's questions.

- Hex's gameplay is deep, complex, and rewarding. If you've played Magic: The Gathering, Hex will be instantly familiar, but Hex goes beyond Magic with mechanics that could only be accomplished in a digital game. Cards that create other cards, cards that can be modified by socketing them with gems, permanent modifiers that follow a card even if it goes into your crypt or back into your deck, and effects that happen in secretly without your opponent's knowledge are just the tip of the iceberg. If you're coming from a background with Hearthstone or other simpler CCGs, or if you have no TCG background whatsoever, buckle up, because you're in for a wild ride.

- Hex has the best, most polished interface for any digital TCG, and it's still improving with every patch.

- Card design and balance is fantastic. Even 9 months into a PvP set, the metagame is still vibrant, evolving, and far from solved in either Constructed or Draft.

- The PVE campaign (while currently very short) is a lot of fun, and the merger of RPG and TCG mechanics works very well.

- The Hex development team are fantastic. They're honest, transparent, and generally very responsive about problems that crop up.

- Hex support is prompt and generous to a fault. If you run into a bug (because let's face it, this is a digital game -- bugs happen) in a PvP tournament that even might have cost you the match, you will usually get your tournament entry refunded in full, in addition to whatever prizes you win from the tournament.

The Bad:
- Hex currently has a somewhat limited selection of formats (no 2v2 multiplayer, no cube drafting, no house rules etc.), and being a digital game, you can't easily make up your own without the developer's support.

- The pace of development over the last 2 years has been about half as fast as it should have been. This creates long periods of doldrums where a PvP set or campaign chapter has been current too long and players start to get bored of it (example: Armies of Myth, the current PvP set will have been current for 9 months when the next set, Primal Dawn, finally replaces it). The developers claim that new content should be speeding up, and I believe them, but there's the very real possibility that it won't speed up by as much as anyone would like.

The Ugly:
- Buying Platinum through Steam gets you 10% less for your money than buying from Hex directly. If you want to buy Platinum, do it through the Gameforge[en.hex.gameforge.com] website instead. After listening to community feedback, they lowered the price of platinum on Steam. I still encourage you to buy through Gameforge, though, as it supports the developers slightly more.

- The game is going through some growth pains after the Steam launch and the servers have gone down a few times. This is not typical -- the servers are rock solid 99% of the time outside of major launches.

I absolutely love HEX!  In my opinion, it's simply the best TCG ever made.  I was excited about HEX from the moment I learned about it, and I played the beta a whole lot before the game launched on Steam.  The game is free to play and it's easy to farm loot to improve your deck for free (using the in-game Auction House).  If you want to invest in your card collection, this game is an affordable addiction to develop--and your cards have real world value too!

I used to play TCGs with friends in person and wanted a good single player TCG experience after I no longer had anyone to play with.  The PVE side of HEX is superb!  You can enjoy the RPG style campaign or test your deck against the Frost Arena for a nice payout.  Before the campaign came, I used to love grinding through the Arena over and over again--I love building and testing out new decks.  I haven't been playing the Arena lately because the campaign is so much fun.

For the more competitive players, HEX has so much to offer.  You can play a practice match against your friends or someone you meet in chat, or jump into draft or constructed tournament to win some nice prizes.  There are beginner's drafts as well, so you can get in on the fun without knowing everything there is to know about every card available.

There is no good reason not to try HEX, honestly.  Even if you've never played a TCG before, you should try HEX.

Graphics are gorgeous, I have GTX 980m and am using Dynamic Super Resolution of 4k on my 1080p screen, truly gorgeous, especially on a IPS color monitor panel.

I also love how the story is not invasive, just little quick bits in between playing in the campaign, very cool.

Only downside for me so far is the music gets a little repetitive, but like with most TCG's. who am I kidding, all TCG's, it's more fun to turn off in-game sound and listen to personal music collections anyway. Cheers everyone and have fun! Hex has been a very refreshing experience and one I will not regret dropping $50 on, unlike the latest Hearthstone expansion every four months. ^^

reviewText:
Disclaimer: Kickstarter backer, beta participant, etc.

HEX: Shards of Fate is an absolute gem of a game that is, unfortunately, marked with a few scratches from it's development process thus far. I will make no excuses for the time it has taken to reach this incomplete state or the fact that this is being marketed as a complete product despite lacking many quality of life updates, a more comprehensive tutorial, UI updates, and many of the things promised to backers. I am also not going to pretend that this is the normal kind of 'F2P' game when monetary investments pay off big time, it's more a game you pay for and which you can earn free stuff. I am not here to praise or linger on it's faults - HEX is what it is and what it can be is not what needs to be reviewed and considered here.

If, and only if, you can tolerate a game with scratches and scuffs and clear signs of needed improvement everywhere you turn your head you will find that the game has a lot to offer you but for an optimal experience you are going to have to go beyond the game itself. You'll need to reach out to the community for help with some free cards to fill your meager starter collection, you'll need to look into how things work beyond the lackluster tutorial, and you'll need to learn to love a lot of the flaws as the game grows and gets bigger and better. This is not a polished perfect product that will give you a handy in the parking lot of Wendys for a smile, you have to earn that handy.

But it's a pretty good one. HEX offers a solid introductory PvE experience, drafting is fun, the Arena is enjoyable, PvP has it's charm if you're willing to put in the money, and overall the community is pretty kind (although they certainly didn't put their best foot forward downvoting every review into oblivion that wasn't giving the game it's own hand job) and helpful. I honestly think that if you are interested in a TCG experience that is better than everything else on the market today (and believe me, I have been around to every stall and shop in town) and you can tough it out for a bit? You're going to enjoy it.

No. You're going to love it. HEX isn't in it's best suit and tie right now but if the word of anonymous strangers on the internet means anything it cleans up real nice, all of your girlfriends will be super jealous of it when it's get in the tux and shows up to prom.  If you have any specific questions that are less about sexual innuendo or metaphors and more about concrete concerns feel free to comment and ask, I'd be happy to offer my thoughts. I would love to see HEX succeed and I want to do what I can to make that happen.

That has only something to do with parking lot handys.

reviewText:
Just for frames of reference, I've played the following card games: MtG, YuGiOh, HearthStone, and Net Runner.

HEX: Shards of Fate is a digital tcg that has a single player vs AI component as well.

As a competitive tcg the play is very fun and the mechanics are a natural extension of the mechanics of traditional physical card games. Competitive play will cost money (either buying cards), or paying to enter limited tournaments, but if you're a tcg fan, the experience is everything you'd expect and hope for.

As a single player game vs AI the game is quite fun as well. There is a campaign mode that tells a story as you progress through, grow a character, and gain new cards for future encounters.

Some general pros and cons that I have are:

Pros:
Very fun mechanics both in the traditional tcg sense, but also the campaign in which you have characters that can level in the realm of a card game.

Free to play system in which you can earn rewards and sell them on the auction house to other players.

Continued development! More tcg sets and more missions in the campagin.

Cons:
The campaign story telling is a little sad. Characters sometimes respond the same way even with different races, and it doesn't make much sense. In the initial introductory mission, you feel like the races are different, but then when the other missions take place it feels very generic.

The auction house needs some work. It works for now, but it's pretty clunky.

As the game is still young and is in active growing development, there are some growing pains. If you're a patient person and can deal with this from time to time, I would actually say that this is a good thing (they are constantly improving!)

----

Overall, if you've played any trading or collectable card games I would highly recommend this game.

If you've never played one before, I think HEX is actually one of the best places to start because you can play vs the AI in a nice and relaxed environment free of the stress (because the AI doesn't care).

Would definitely recommend!

reviewText:
Ignore the hours listed here, I put well over 1000 hours into Hex before the Steam launch. I was a Kickstarter backer and have been playing since the Alpha.

Hex is one of my absolute favorite games. It's one of the best card games I've ever played, and blows away every other digital TCG.

A couple points:
1) Is it free to play?
You CAN play 100% free. The entire PvE experience is completely free. You can play the full campaign. You can earn the PvE cards and equipment as loot from playing. None of that requires spending a dime.

The PvP has a cost associated with it, BUT that cost doesn't have to be money. PvP booster packs are purchased with platinum (the real money currency). However, you can sell/trade your PvE loot for platinum or PvP cards/packs. So, you can play 100% free as long as you are willing to invest some time into the PvE to earn platinum.

2) Is it pay to win?
No. It's a TCG, and the PvP does follow the traditional TCG model of buying booster packs. However, as mentioned above, you can earn those packs/cards via just playing the game and trading. You CAN pay for more packs/cards which will give you more options, but they don't make you stronger or better than someone else. A skilled player is much more dangerous than a good deck.

3) How does this compare to Hearthstone?
This game is a little bit slower, but is a lot more strategic. The main advantage that Hex has is being able to play cards on your opponent's turn. This makes a HUGE difference in strategy. It gives the player a lot more control and a lot more options. The other difference is that the defender declares blockers. It allows you to make a lot more strategic defensive decisions. And to go along with that... damage to troops is not permanent. This changes the gameplay from fast paced cycling of creatures to something with a lot more interesting decisions. Overall, Hex is just a deeper, more strategic game.

Also, the PvE in Hex blows away Hearthstones by a mile. It's much more in depth with character customization, quests, story nodes, full dungeons, varied paths to take, etc.

4) How does this compare to Magic: The Gathering?
It is very similar. Hex obviously took a lot of inspiration from MTG, but Hex does plenty to differentiate itself. The resource system is similar at first glance, but there are a lot of nuanced differences. The decoupling of threshold from costs has a lot of interesting things that go along with it (being able to play multiple cards of a color with a single threshold, or having cards with a threshold cost higher than their actual resource cost, for example).

Permanent effects! That's right, effects are permanent and persist through various changes. A buffed creature that is returned to your hand or placed into your deck retains these buffs even after being re-drawn and/or played. This leads to a lot of interesting options.

Digital only mechanics. There are a lot of mechanics in Hex that just wouldn't work (or would be very tedious to attempt) in a physical card game. For example, the prophecy mechanic affects the next card of a certain type in your deck when the card with prophecy is played. The permanent/persistent effects wouldn't really work in a physical card game. Tons of these types of things exist throughout Hex which make for a very interesting experience.

Champions/Charge powers. You have a champion with a specific power. When a resource is played you get a charge (there are other ways to get charges as well, but this is the basic method). The charge power has a specific cost to activate. These powers vary from simple things such as just drawing a card to buffing all troops that share a type. These are not only interesting additions from a strategic point of view, but also help combat resource flood as you'll be able to activate the charge power with those resources.

Then there's the PvE... which there is no equivalent to. If you like MTG there is a good chance you'll enjoy Hex as well.

5) Can you really make money from this game?
Yes! Not only was there recently a $100,000 tournament, but you can sell your in-game items (cards, packs, etc) for real money via third party trading. These cards DO have a value! There are plenty of third party sites set up in which you can either sell/buy directly with a store or with other players.

Summary
If you like deep strategic card games, then you owe it to yourself to check this game out. If you like single player card games, you'll love the PvE. If you like competitive card games, there's plenty of that in various forms (Constructed, Sealed, and Draft with both synchronous and asynchronous modes). This is one of the best card games out there!

reviewText:
I have been playing Hex for a little over two years now. I had never kickstarted a game before, never played a beta let alone an alpha, so this was quite an interesting experience for me. I came to this game because I love TCGs, and I needed convenience to play one. I had played Magic when it first came out, but as a kid, I never understood how big it would get. Later in life I would try to play the WoW tcg, but quickly found that being a physical game had restrictions when you had adult responsibilities to adhere too. Hex allows me to have all that I love in TCG, and play in big tournaments from home.

But the game has become so much more then that. The community of the game is some of the best I have ever had the pleasure of being apart of. I really like a lot of the streamers, and people that I interact with on a weekly basis. The game does innovative things, because it exists solely in a digital environment without physical restrictions. The game has a passionate team that communicate with us, and drive the game through amazing leaps and bounds, always getting better then it was before. Hex provides a free to play Player verse Environment area where people can win cards, equipment, and gold to continually improve their decks, and collections. Staunch grinders can reputedly make enough gold, to actually draft now and then furthering their collection. Talented draft players and auction has savvy individuals have been able to go infinite, and amass a collection without having to drop money into the game all the time. Streamers and community members do giveaways, and help new people out, as they enter into the game and start learning what the game has to offer.

The game offers up options for several kinds of players. Collectors, competitive players, free to play players, and you can just play the campaign for fun.

This isn't to say that the game doesn't have flaws.

Hex is a small company, with a limited staff, trying to do huge amazing things, in a variety of areas. This is a huge under taking. Because of this production time can be slow at times, communication can sometimes become strained, and vague. Sometimes they will make choices that people don't agree with. The tutorial and introduction to hex has grown by leaps and bounds but still sometimes confuses people. Lastly, many of the promises from the kickstarter have yet to be delivered, and that scares new people, and infuriates some older people. The initial campaign is a little short, and the replay-ability is not as good as it could be.

Despite these flaws the game is well worth while. The company continues to add staff, and create a foundation, that makes the next step easier, smoother and more efficient. Production time, and deadlines are getting faster, and I have faith will eventually work like a well oiled machine, producing PVP, PVE and events in a fashion that at the very least every couple of months something new is happening. As new people come in, and talk to veterans, staff members, the helpful Nobles, and talk on our forums, the game will improve. Kickstarter rewards are slowly being checked off, and the majority of the Kickstarters have accepted the delay with grace and poise, while still letting them know they don't want to be forgotten, and Hex continues to prove that we won't be. When they make a mistake and the people talk to them in reasonable ways, letting them know how they feel, they consider our words very carefully. If it was indeed a mistake, then they are quick to find a solution, always putting us first. Sometimes they make a choice that we don't agree with, and after careful consideration they stand firm. I personally have experienced this, and feel that in those edge cases, they are doing what they think is right, and I believe that they can see the bigger picture then I can, so I put my faith in them. The adventure zones will continues to come, enhancing and expanding the game, the focus will broaden, and the secrets that are hidden in the lore, will slowly come to the surface. Choices will go from making small effects in small places, to large effects that ripple through the story.

Lastly I want to stress something that I think is often missed in a game like this. If you find the campaign short, if you love playing draft casually but maybe don't like the meta. Walk away, and take a break. I have through these two years, had to for one reason or another slow down, or take a break from the game. When something new draws me back, I am always excited to jump into the new tasty treats with gusto. Sometimes though, you just got to take a break. That doesn't mean you have to leave forever. Come back when your not burned out, when something new excites you, or whatever.

Remember the game is free to download, free to try, free to talk to others who are playing. Taste it, and see if Hex is right for you.

Disregard my played time so far, I've been playing this game as one of the earliest Kickstarter backers and have hundreds if not over a thousand hours ingame outside the Steam client.  Simply, this game is EVERYTHING I have wanted in a TCG.

- The community is amazing.  It is by far the most helpful and friendly of any game I've played.  Clearly things may change with the massive influx this new platform will bring, but the core playerbase (supported by the devs) has cultivated something truely special.
- Similarly, the developers have done right by the community the vast majority of the time.  It's clear and apparent they care deeply about building a strong ethical reputation with their playerbase.
- It plays similar to MTG, but the digital only realm vastly expands available mechanics, interactions, and future potential.
- Free to play PVE currency (gold) actually has a valuable transaction rate to premium currency (platnum). With some patience and understanding of the economy you can easily transition into buying packs, tournament entires etc.  In game assets can be purchased with EITHER currency as reasonable prices through the in-game auction house.
- The art and audio are fantastic, the atmosphere is stellar.

- This game has unfortunately suffered from multiple delays development wise.  While this is certainly a negative, I feel that the attention, and try and do right by the players attitude mitigates my frustrations with the slow development place.  I anticipate future PVE and PVP releases to be at a much more acceptable cadence.
- Some of the lore is...discordant.  I enjoy the vast majority of it, however there are certain aspects that seem out of place or that I don't personally care for.  This is clearly in the eye of the beholder but some players may be slightly turned off by it.  I do not recommend the Hex novel.
- As of yet unimplemented features.  The potential is there and the rest of the game is SO good, that it makes waiting for promised but un-implemented features all the more painful.  Per above, Im hopeful development and release speed should improve dramatically.

All said and done
date: I would (and have) recommended this game to a wide and diverse set of people.  It's worth spending at least a few hours ingame before forming your opinion as much of the game really starts to shine once you have an appreciation for how all the systems interact.\n\nDEFINATELY TRY THIS GAME."

reviewText:
I've been playing Hex since Alpha, and played MTGO for years prior to that. With that frame of reference, I find Hex better in most ways to what MTGO brings to the table and wholeheartedly recommend the game. The great thing is, if you have even a passing interest, the PVE Campaign in Hex is completely free to play, so you can try it out with no investment. Technically you can grind enough to play the PVP side of the game without buying in as well, but it's a very long grind.

There are things MTGO does better:
Variety of formats - Hex is still limited to about four tournament formats that are supported in client and fire with any regularity. MTGO has more formats than I care to count and the player base to support them.
Depth of PVP play - Hex is about to release set 4, so currently has fewer than 1000 cards available for PVP, whereas MTGO draws from the entire history of Magic
Draft Interface - I love the draft interface in the new MTGO client, and the Hex draft interface, while serviceable, pales in comparison.

Everything else I feel is in Hex's favor, and much of these factors are so much better than MTGO that the comparison is laughable:
- Graphics and presentation of gameplay is much more engaging, the music is beautiful and lends itself well to the setting
- The overall UI is much easier to use (the one exception being the chat" function
date:
which is meh)
- There is meaningful PVE play that awards cards and gold which can be used to buy more cards in the Auction House
- There's an Auction House to easily buy and sell cards and other items
- The game makes fantastic use of the digital space with innovative gameplay that MTGO can never replicate while it is tied to the tabletop game
- The price is roughly half of what MTGO costs for similar events/tournaments/etc.

Note about price: yes
recommended: you are most likely going to need to invest to play PVP. This is the same with the direct competition which is MTGO
hoursPlayed: but the price to buy-in to Hex is roughly half what you pay in MTGO for similar experiences
voteText: and you are more likely to get a return on your investment that helps fund further activities. Just don't go in thinking "free to play" means you can easily grind the whole game; it applies mostly to the PVE play."

Early impressions, proper review to follow:

F2P TCG clearly made with great care from the developers.  Single player RPG like campaign, various tournaments and play modes, card trading auction house, CHAT on a very robust game client that's a joy to be on.

PVE and versus matches use separate decks and progression.  Compared to some other F2P card games out there, HEX is quite a bit heavier on the monotonous gold grinding for purchasing cards/packs, especially before you collect enough cards to make a cheap competitive deck.

Take notes, Wizards of the Coast.  THIS is how it's done.

If you have even a passing interest in CCG/TCG's, and haven't tried HEX, DO SO NOW.

As always, I can't expect everyone to agree with a subjective review, but if you decide to thumb it down I would appreciate hearing what should be improved!

reviewText:
PROS:
• Engaging gameplay.  Similar to MtG, but with enough unique features to gameplay (like being able to track changes to cards, having full cards generated instead of just token, the champion/avatar system) that make HEX games just fun to play.
•  HEX has AMAZING art.  Each card has exceptional art.  I was around in MtG's early days and HEX is nothing like that.  In fact, HEX art now in many cases is a step above what MtG currently has.
• A pretty welcoming community.  Being a game that was Kickstarted means that there are already some veterans in the game since the beta that are always looking out to help their fellow players.

CONS:
• The biggest complaint I can leverage is that development seems to be a little slow.  The game shows great promise (and as mentioned, beautiful), but new features seem to come along a bit slow considering the genre.
• While marketed as F2P, it really isn't.  It is very cheap for a trading card game, but a significant investment of time would be required for a person to play the PvP sections without ever spending a dime.  It's possible, but probably not the best way the game should be played.

Overall, though, I heartily recommend the game and I think that it will only increase in quality with time.

reviewText:
Hex is a deep trading card game that embraces its digital nature, with mechanics not feasible in meatspace.  Whether you're a TCG veteran or a newbie, competetive or not, you'll find something to love in this game.

The PVE campaign combines the depth of a trading card game with traditional RPG elements (classes, levelling, skill trees) to make for a great experience.  The campaign is completely free-to-play, you'll earn cards and gold you can use to improve your deck, as well as any cards you get from playing the PVP side of the game.  There's several hours of content here with much more in the works.

For the competetive types, PVP definitely can stand on its own.  Unlike the campaign, PVP is generally pay-to-play outside of friendly constructed games or player-driven leagues.  Tournaments consist of limited formats such as draft and sealed and competetive constructed where you bring your own deck.  Limited formats are a great place to start if you haven't built up a collection yet, as everyone is limited to the packs they use in the event.

reviewText:
EDIT: As of 4/22/2016, Plat pricing on the steam client is now in line with the standalone!

Dont let the game time fool you, I've put a ridiculous amount of time into this game since last september.
Hex got me hooked almost immediately. As a long-time MTG player (started around 1st Mirrodin block) I was able to pick up the basics of the game fairly quickly. But even now I'm still discovering new card interactions and ways to play. Don't get me wrong, I adore Magic, but I've drifted away from the card shop scene, and Magic's digital offerings are completely garbage. Hex, while fairly similar to Magic in many ways (part of the appeal to me imho), has enough uniqueness to both set it apart from Magic and elevate it in many ways.
Hex fully embraces the possibilities of a digital-only card game, and I can't wait to see what Primal Dawn (set 4) will bring to the table.

---

Pros:
-Digital nature allows for some truly bonkers card design. Super fun!
-Collection has real value
-PvP is competitive and fun, even though I still suck at limited :P. Will be even better once ladders are implemented.
-PvE was a blast my first time through, and I still keep coming back with new characters and decks. Lots of potential. Wish there were more character slots though.
-Legitimately one of the best communities in gaming. You run into the occasional salt factory in pvp every so often, but most people are super friendly and willing to help out newbies. When I first started people were giving me tons of tips that really helped me learn the game. A few players even sent me cards to fill out my collection some more! Now that I'm a more established player I've been doing that myself.
-Dev team listens to players and are very passionate about their game.

---

Cons
-A little bit more RNG than I'd like in some of the card designs.
-Devs can be slow to release content and are a bit afraid to post release dates for content, which is a source of frustration among the community. I'm sympathetic, and the devs are definitely making an effort to improve this, but this could turn off some people.

---

A note for new players: Presumably due to the cut that steam takes out of sales, you get about 10% less plat when purchasing through the steam game client than you would in the standalone client or on the website. I would recommend players to go to us.hex.gameforge.com, visit the my account" page

reviewText:
On the surface everything it fine with this game, however the more time you spend with it you start see more and more problems. Some commenters already pointed them already but here are the main issues from my point of view:

- The free to play" label is misleading because after just the first day you realise you need to invest real cash and/or lot of grind time to actually make any progression (expanding your card collection). A new player has no chance to finish the first PVE chapter without buying some extra cards or having an insane luck (read "tons of frustration" until it happens).

- The development of the game started years ago and even the crowdfunding was very successful (based on their MMOTCG vision) they delivered just a really short chapter with almost no interactions with other players (at this point you can only chat and buy/sell cards via AH). Other than that it is a single player experience.

- In order to participate to PVP events you need to buy tickets (with platinum). You can buy platinum directly from the cash shop or grind gold (invest in a good deck) and convert it to items (cards
date:
boosters or equipment) and sell those via AH for platinum.

-The strategy of Cryptozoic is focused on luring new people into playing and don't care too much about retaining them. This was visible from the starting campaign when they offered ridiculous overpowered rewards for backers. Too bad for the others. Later when community was screaming for PVE content they preferred on heavily investing and promoting their PVP tournament. Some bugs are present unfixed since alpha (eg Forge of Cadoc) and in addition things that were fine are broken after updates (eg. Arena challenges rewards). My general impression is they bite more than they can chew.

To be fair I would like to add also some positive comments:

- Even if their roots are visible connected with the MtG on the launching set
recommended:
they put serious efforts to differentiate from those by creating new mechanics and exploiting the digital aspect of the cards.

- The game looks polish and in general the quality of artworks is quite high (except the character portraits who look a bit rushed).

- It is a great idea with huge potential

Product received for free

As of 22 May 2016:

I'm a CCG player from way back, starting with MtG's Antiquities expansion. The Hex experience really brought back the memories of those early days: Solid mechanics, a fun way to spend some time, addictive but not brutally so.

The down side is, there's only a single 'Adventure Zone' (AZ1) right now. So if you're in it for the PvE experience, you'll have to replay the same content with a bunch of different character types. After a while that gets stale.

Still, it's worth 10 hours of your time to see if you like the mechanics and general gameplay. If so, and you also like the PvP aspect, you're off and running. If you like it but mostly for the PvE content, then you can keep tabs on the updates and jump back in when AZ2 is released, which is supposed to be 'soon (TM)'.

reviewText: Somewhere at the crossroads of Magic: the Gathering and Hearthstone, you have Hex. Hex is all the pros of an intricate and interactive TCG like Magic with the benefits of a sleek online interface like Hearthstone. Having been on the market for several years already, Hex provides a massive amount of content for new and veteran TCG players alike. The single-player campaign is a singularly unique experience as it seeks to emulate MMO's in storytelling, questing, loot, and more while retaining all the deckbuilding and gameplay challenges you'd expect from a TCG. The PVP content sports a myriad of traditional archetypes with unique twists and sports a low entry cost for the genre. Hex offers numerous formats in which to battle fellow players, whether it's in the Constructed Gauntlet, a traditional Draft, or a competitive tournament. Hex delivers a fresh look at an old genre while retaining everything you've come to love from a TCG.\n\nQuick note for new players: There are usually packs for sale for Gold in the Auction House. You can also go to the trade chat to trade your Gold for Platinum to buy packs or singles.

reviewText: This is a really impressive card game, a lot of reviews already say it but it's Magic: The Gathering taken to the next level, it builds on that already solid foundation and capitalizes on the digital medium by introducing all kinds of effects that would either be too cumbersome to keep track of as a table top card game or simply would logistically be possible. reviewText:
I have been playing Hex regularly since the start of the closed beta, over 2 years ago. Raptr says I have logged 707 hours in the game prior to Steam Launch. I know not all of my time got properly tracked.

HEX IS AMAZING. I've logged more hours in Hex than any other game.

This is not just a game. It is a hobby. It will own your heart for years. There alre lots of other positive reviews. So, I'll keep mine to a few few things I think you need to understand going into it.

1 - THERE'S A LOT OF DEPTH - We already have hundreds of cards in 3 sets, and the 4th major set comes out next week. Accept that it will take time to understand everything. The community is very good about helping new players out. You're not going to be elite an hour after you finish the tutorial.

2 - UNDERSTAND THE ECONOMY - This is not F2P where everything is handed to you on a silver platter. The PVE campaign and Frost Ring Arena are free to play. These are good places to learn how the game works, and earn some gold to buy more cards from the Auction House (Or sell your cards for the premium currency, Platinum). Hex makes its money selling booster packs and entrance fees to tournaments, like traditional TCGs. These items can be purchased from gold with time, but it isn't quick.

3 - PAY TO COMPETE (Not Pay to Win!!!!!) - It absolutely is possible to trade gold for packs and plat, and turn that around to going infinite with skilled play. That's not realistic for most of us. If you want to play in draft or sealed tournaments regularly, get comfortable with supporting the developers with the purchase of plat. This is a very traditional TCG business model.

Costs are EXTREMELY REASONABLE
For a booster draft (assuming 100 plat = $1):
$2 per booster x 3 packs = $6
+100 plat ($1) entry fee = $7.
If you play Swiss draft, you'll play 3 rounds. That's 3 hours of entertainment for $7, which is a better value than going to a movie - and you can sell some of those cards to finance more drafts. You get a booster for each win, so even at 1-2, you're getting more than the entry cost.

Compare the costs of Hex to Magic: The Gathering, or any other TCG, and I think the value speaks for itself.

The game is not Pay to Win
date: because there is a lot of skill involved in Hex. You can have decks full of legendary cards and still get wrecked by smarter players. I know this cause I'm the one with the legendaries who loses in big tournaments =) But I keep coming back for more.\n\nDownload the game. Watch Cory's release video. Get ready to enjoy Hex for years to come. Welcome to the party!

reviewText:
According to Raptr, this is, by far, my most-played game with over 1300 hours put in: http://raptr.com/Warrender/games?sort_by=hours_played

It's Magic: The Gathering for the 21st centuy.

MTG players will be at home with its mechanics and be delighted by the new ones made possible only in a digital medium.  There is a competitive PVP scene ranging from free ingame community tournaments to a recent Invitational which awarded $100,000 in cash prizes.  It's a true TCG with the emphasis on Trading.  Unlike CCG's like Hearthstone, players can trade or sell their cards which means their collection will always have value.

The PVE content is small for now but more is promised on the way.  You can fight against the AI in a campaign to level a character or in the arena to grind for gold, the ingame currency which has real value.  Gold can be used to buy cards or equipment on the ingame Auction House.  You can even trade gold for plat (the currency you buy with cash) to other players by using the ingame mail COD system.

The game is free to try and you get 200 cards to start your collection off.  More cards can be won in the PVE campaign and the wonderful community has even been known to give away cards to newbies who ask nicely.

reviewText:
Having been a long time TCG player (MTG since Arabian Nights!), Hex has brought to the digital space an amazing new take, being able to do things with card and game mechanics that just aren't possible with a TCG that also has to conform to a physical card game.  Add to this the new PVE content which fits my solo play style, and I've found my heaven.

While technically this is a free to play game (and infact you are given a good number of cards by completing tutorials and playing the PVE campaign), if your goal is to complete in constructed PvP, you will likely end up spending money or time.  However, there are also limited PvP competition options, like drafting (where everyone is on the same foot, only relying on knowledge of cards, deck buidling, and lady luck in what is passed/opened), or swiss style where you open packs and create your deck from that pool.

Over all, while I still play other games, this is my go-to when it comes to TCG's.  I highly recommend giving it a try, since you can try for free.  Play through the tutorials and some of the PvE campaign to get a feel and aquire some free cards and in-game currency (gold).  Before jumping into PvP, watch some of the many Twitch streamers for draft pointers and to get a feel for the game mechanics.  And if you have questions, ask in chat.  The community is awsome and loves to help out with whatever info you might need.

reviewText:
So, what to say about Hex?

I first learnt about Hex from the Penny Arcade comic linking to the enormously successful Kickstarter campaign. Every part of the promise in the Kickstarter excited me - a Magic the Gathering like game I could play on my computer, designed for online play from the ground up, with robust PvP, drafts, sealed tournaments, constructed - all for a fraction of the price of Magic. Great, sign me up! But wait, there's more! A fully fledged RPG, exploring an open world, levelling up your character, unlocking new traits, working together with friends to take down raid bosses, a full guild system, and tons of cards and equipment to collect. Okay, that sounds amazing. And I won't lie - a big part of what excited me was being a part of such a great game right from the start. I'm sure many people have wished they could have played Magic from the days of Alpha and just had boxes of Moxes and Lotuses. And here was my chance with Hex!

So, has Hex delivered on those promises? Well, partially. The game itself is awesome, and every bit as fun as they made it out to be (I wouldn't have played at least a full draft tournament every week since they were launched back in 2014 if it wasn't!). PvP is great - it's a really fun draft, sealed and costructed format, and everyone is looking forwards to the release of the new set, Primal Dawn, next week.

Now, the PvE side of things has been lagging behind. But this year we're finally starting to be rewarded for our patience, as they added the first major update to campaign. Granted, this is far behind the original release schedule (the very first release date speculation of hopefully full release by end of the year" given during the 2013 Kickstarter now seems laughable in hindsight). But the promises are now starting to be made good on
