Context:  I am a kickstarter backer for this game, so there is probably some bias. I've played hundreds of hours in their beta period on their standalone client doing drafts and more recently PvE.

TLDR:  Just plain recommend for PvP and the normal CCG part of the game (ie spending money/packs on drafts or tournaments).  Recommend waiting till more updates with end game features come if you just want to do PvE. I am going to keep playing.

I will not talk about how much I enjoy the game beyond that I find it fun in both the PvE and PvP aspects.  I can't really comment on the Free to Play and how easy/hard it is to make viable decks for PvE without having put money in.  It looks to be a lot of effort, but the PvE is good at handing out small packs with both PvP and PvE cards.  It also hands out individual cards through quests and various interactions with the game map (playing multiple characters is a free way to get a playset of the individual card awards).

I want to talk about how Cryptozoic is adding additional content, the card set schedule, and general updating and patching of the game.

Good news is that they patch and update pretty frequently, and give pretty good notice for when they take the servers down.  They are very communicative with their playerbase, and are really encouraging of community based events.  They would naturally love it if a player decided to stream the game.

I in general like their card set schedule, which is apparently ending up to match Magic's.  I imagine now that it is released on Steam and they have 4 sets (4th Set on April 26, 2016) under their belt they've got a release strategy going.  What I don't know is how often they are going to add PvE content and PvE card sets.  They have made statements, but then they've had to delay before and they will probably have to again.  My outsider perspective is that development has been rough for them.

Don't necessarily go in expecting to be able to hit lvl cap and start doing raids.  Raids don't exist yet, and lvl cap is currently lvl 9 of I believe 30.  Multiple of the stated classes are not in the game yet.  Guilds do not exist yet.  Keeps, see their kickstarter for what that is, do not exist yet.  Double backs, again kickstarter, are not in.  Mercenaries, again kickstarter...actually check their website they've changed what mercs will be/do a lot, are just inventory items at the moment.

They release about two big features a year, and in general touch every previous feature with some polish as well.  One for this year was the first PvE zone, character creation/leveling, story based dungeons.  With that release schedule and now having to release new PvE content several times a year, I imagine they will be feature complete to the kickstarter in mid 2017 to late 2018.

If you're willing to get in early for PvE, or just want to play PvP drafts/tournaments (ie spend money) I think its a great purchase and a fun CCG that does some real interesting things.  If you want to solely do the PvE, and maybe venture into PvP when you've earned enough packs/currency from the dual currency AH to buy in then I would recommend waiting a year or two and coming back when its more feature complete.

reviewText:
I've been a long time TCG fan, hacing played pokemon, yu-gi-oh, duel masters, and even harry potter tcgs in my youth, and Magic: The Gathering for much of my high school and college years. This game is what I've been waiting for, a digital TCG that rivals MTG. I have been playing since very early on, having backed it on kickstarter, and probalby have a few hundred hours in on the stand alone client.

The game is well thought out mechanically and introduces several mechanics that would be nigh impossible to acomplish in a physical TCG, however these mechanics are far from mere gimmicks. While you have cards such as Cosmic Transmogrifier which turn their entire board into a chaos of random cards, you also have mechanics such as escalate and prophecy, which buff cards that are still in your deck, and cards which can add new cards to your deck which don't even exist outside the instance of the game. Cards retaining their buffs and debuffs permanantly is a feature that really shakes things up. If you're playing against an opponent who uses cards which can be brought back to life, killing the 1/1 they buffed to a 10/10 might not be enough when he comes back with all the buffs still intact. Indeed, a lot of cards affect eachother before they even hit the field, modifying the cards in your hand and deck adds an interesting layer of strategy to the game.

Another nice addition in Hex is the PvE elements. Currently only the first chapter of the campaign is inplace, but players can choose from 4 races and 3 classes, soon to be expanded to more options, and these race/class compinations have large effects on your decks, from deciding which cards you cna use to buffing certain aspects of cards and your own character. Having the PvE seperate from the PvP also gives Hex the oppretunity to create insane cards that would be considered too unruly or imbalanced for tournament play, many PvE cards have super fun mechanics, such as Holiday which can become a random troop each turn, or are just insanely powerful, such as Wraith of Zaakir which turns you into an almight dragon cabable of incinerating your opponent's troops.

All in all I highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of TCGs. Yes, you have to buy cards if you want to compete, but you have to in any TCG, and with packs only costing 2USD, it's probably one of the cheapest ones out there. Not to mention the regular draft tournaments being played, and the active and involved community. This makes it a no-brainer to any TCG fan who wants to play a game which they don't need to drive to the card shop anad hope someone is playing.

I kickstarted HEX day 1 and been playing since first day of Alpha. I come from a TCG background, mostly MTG and WOW-TCG.

For me this game is everything Hearthstone and Magic Online is not. Hearthstone has to shallow rules, Magic Online is unpolished and expensive. There are also free touranments with 100+ players each weekend (confirmed for at least 2 more months at the time I'm writing this)

The game has problems. The developer, HEX Entertainment is new with developing games and it shows. There are bugs, and have been delays in features. But one thing they have shown throughout the entire lifetime of the game is that they want to do right by the players. Another thing is the passion. You can feel how passionate the developers are when playing.

The community is probably one of the best I've been a part of. Most are friendly and might even give away commons and uncommons to new players. This game is the closest you can get to a paper TCG and by far the best digital card game around!

reviewText:
I've been playing TCG's competitively for close to 22 years.  I have played a vast majority of TCGs at the highest level for most of my adult gaming life.  I have never played a game that has as much promise has Hex does.  There are obvious parallels drawn to Magic, and they're not off-base in the respect that the foundation for Hex is similar to Magic.  However, after getting past the core premise, the game diverges in significant ways.

The easy comparison is to discuss some of the PvP aspects, which includes Booster Draft, Sealed Deck, and Constructed formats.  Hex also has an asynchronous 'Gauntlet' tournament format which is similar to Hearthstone Arena.  You get to play at your convenience.  Since a lot of the keywords are similar, and the match structure is similar, PvP Hex does feel like Magic.  A better version (obviously that's my opinion), but it is similar.  Especially with the last 2 sets (and the upcoming 4th set which is about to release) the Hex team has expanded the scope of the cards in ways that a physical TCG just can't do, whether it be putting cards into your opponents decks, making permanent changes to cards in decks, etc.

However, currently where Hex really sets itself apart is in its PvE offerings.  It's taken a bit longer than most anticipated getting off the ground, but the Hex single-player experience truly has a robust offering of matches.  You can change your deck in ways that are just not possible in paper tcgs.  Equipment that you obtain (through single player content primarily) modify cards in your deck.  There are PvE-specific cards that can have ultra powerful effects on the game, that just can't happen in PvP due to power constraints.

I could literally type pages about the bright future of Hex, but I'll just summarize with the standard Pros/Cons

Pros:
- Healthy PvP metagame, vital to the success of any TCG
- Robust single-player experience, truly a focus for the Hex team
- Cards have real value:  while entry to PvP _generally_ isn't free, this is mitigated by the fact that cards have real world value.

Cons:
- A less-than desirable delay between sets, that is shortening with greater amounts of framework being laid each expansion
- The servers don't seem quite set up to handle the large influx of Steam players nonstop.  New players need to note: this is not the norm.  The servers are just being worked hard due to a lot of new players.  Overworked server load is common with any large game launch, Hex is not immune

reviewText:
-Highly fun and interactive game. Allows you to respond to opponent instead of playing solitaire, then going AFK on opponent's turn. That might be a pro or a con depending on what kind of game you are looking for.
-The cardbase has a lot of interesting and sound mechanics. It is inspired by previous card games and builds upon them with new mechanics.
-You can trade cards and ingame items. This allows you to build the deck you want and you can trade them away if you change your mind later.
-The game has draft and sealed formats where you keep all the cards you pick/open. Fun way to expand your collection while playing and allows for the potential to go infinite if you are good enough.
-PvE allows people to earn things through just playing. You can trade the things you earn in PvE to other players (gold is the most valued).
-Community is good. People are helpful.

I've been playing for quite a while on the stand-alone client, so my steam game time doesn't reflect my total playtime. I've enjoyed this game, it has replaced all the other card games I've played, and it is only continuing to get better.

reviewText:
I've been playing HEX for a little more than a year. It truly is an amazing digital tcg.
I won't go into a long rant about why the game is good, many other reviewers do this - there's plenty of material to read. Instead, I'd like to sum up some of the pros and cons:

Pros
+Real tcg, you do not only collect cards, you can trade them or sell them on auction house.
+PvE content, arena and campaign. Both earns you gold (ingame currency), cards and equipment.
+Campaign the rpg pve will only grow with time.
+Competitive - If you like how MTG plays out in competitive scene, I'm betting you will also like HEX. Being similar is not a bad thing, but do not think HEX a MTG clone, HEX does a lot of things its own way which makes me come to:
+Digital only TCG. This means HEX has mechanics that is only possible through a digital tcg that can keep track of every buff, debuff and whatnot. Example: Arborean Rootfather ability - 2cost, shuffle it back into the deck and give it cost -2, then draw a card. In a physical tcg if you had multiple copies it would not be easily possible to know which of them had the cost -2.
+Free to play IS possible, also in a competitive scene. However, do not expect it to come rushing in. It takes time, effort, some luck and skill. The beginning is the slowest, but once you get into limited and if you are skilled enough AND can play the auction house you can quickly earn more than you spend. Personally half (and probably a little more) of my card collection is through free to play and where I have been paying has been at the beginning to get started up faster and when I did not want to put in the time and effort to earn myself the platinum and/or cards.
+Complicated. HEX has a lot of depth - you will go into mind games vs. your opponent and choosing the right course of action is a lot more difficult than you would think. This also adds a lot of fun to it, since it is not always so straight forward and your action current turn can make you lose the next, or the one after that.
+UI, Graphics and Sound - they are all excellent. UI is smooth, graphics are nice on the eyes - every function is well polished. It is a great experience overall.
+Content in both PvE and PvP will keep getting expanded.
+Support. The hex support team is AMAZING. Are you having a bug during a draft or sealed? Well, you're in luck, because they are very willing to compensate you fully. All you have to do is go to their support site, login and write a ticket and fill in details (it is important to fill in the # of your tournament).
+The community. HEX has absolutely the best community I have ever experienced in any game. They are helpful, generous, mature and generally nice people. Especially those who are part of the twitch community on hex. I can highly recommend the hex streamers on twitch and have a chat. There's also usually giveaways on various streams for cards or drafts. Also a great place to learn - check it out. No seriously, check it out!

Cons
-Waiting time. I love the game, but they can be very slow at releasing new content and fixing bugs. I'm hopeful though, now that they got their core mechanics (with coding) and PvE campaign it's reasonable to believe content will be released in a more steady flow than previously.
-Complicated. Learning all the mechanics will take time and effort. It is difficult. You have to use your head. You need to learn keywords, priority steps, when to do what, what happens when I do this in response, the list goes on. Even after more than a year I learn new tricks - I do find this _fun_, but getting fundamentals at the beginning can be a frustrating experience for some. Do not give up, get into it and ask around for help or look at guides. Help is everywhere!
-Bugs. Being a digital TCG means bugs will be inevitable. Some are worse than others, but sometimes they stick around for longer than I would like. However, this has not made me want to stop the game, as their support team is insanely good.

Give it a swing, it's free to play after all - but do expect to either spend a lot of time or put in some money if you want to join the competitive scene. I do hope the review helped :-)

Edit: Added a few extra Pros that I at the time did not consider.

TLDR Good game with nice Devs. Auction house needs love. Pve is fun and interesting but some combos give huge road blocks that are difficult to pass without long hours of grinding. Good community. Nice amount of customizing and synergy with cards. A game that actually IS FTP.

As said, I've never played any other tcg before but I was able to get into this one fairly well. The game features RPG elements along with pvp elements which seen to mesh pretty well. You can use the pve or campaign mode to collect some cards and money. You can then take the cards you're not using and sell them at the auction house (more on that later.) The gold can be traded to other players for platinum through the trade window quick, IMHO, works better than the auction house.

From the earnings here you can go to the store and buy different booster packs or sleeves, (things that make the back of the cards look different) for the plat or gold. If that method is too slow for you then you can always spend real money for what you want, though it doesn't really necessitate spending real money.


The auction house is a mess if you ask me. They have different options to sort through cards but you still end up with 20 different pages of the same card. If you are out bid on a card you'll get mail letting you know but no link to that specific cards again I'd your care about that sort of thing.

Many people have negative reviews because of the servers going down when it first launched on steam and it's true they did go down but since then have stabilized so it's a non issue. That isn't too say there aren't issues with the mail but they get resolved within a reasonable amount of time. It is an mmo after all so expect things to happen. The cow of the game is fun. I don't know about them copy pasting from another game and honestly don't really care. The game is fun and the community is helpful. The Devs also are interactive with everyone in chat add well. There's one that had answered so many of my questions I feel like we're on first name bases now lol. Thanks noble!

People have also started to say the game is going to sink because of the company over top it. I don't know anything about this company and don't care. I care about what the game is now and now it's good. That's like jumping off a boat because you think it's going sink even though there isn't a hole in it and no clouds in the sky.

Now the things that get under my skin. There are certain parts of the campaign that don't make to much sense to me. For instance, masonry it where not all cards in your collection are available for you to use our limiting the amount. I'm not talking about only having 3 or 4 cards of a set type in your deck. I'm talking about only being allowed 1 common names card instead of allowing all 3 of your commons from that name to be in your deck. If I'm lvl 3 I'm limited to having 1 common no shard card off a given name in my deck. If I'm lvl 4 I'm allowed 2. For some classes/races this makes some of the fights near impossible because they don't allow you to use the card in your collection that would allow you to pass this. Simply lvling up doesn't really work when you're race/class doesn't get an xp boost so you're only getting 40xp per battle and you need over 2000 for a lvl. This is coming from an avid jrpg gamer. (I own more than what is on my steam account for those who are currently checking my games.)

Good game, good devs good fun.  Don't pass it up.

reviewText:
Hex: Shards of Fate - A wonderful blend of RPG and TCG
THE GOOD
A beautifully fleshed out TCG with fantastic digital mechanics.
A rich free-to-play Campaign experience that pushes the boundaries of traditional TCG concepts.
Unique TCG Customization - expressed by cards, characters, equipment, sockets, and more.
Gorgeous art assets for a TCG; great sound effects and gameboards.
THE BAD
Slow Content Updates - The slow pace of updates may be offputting to some folks.
Time Commitment; Players expecting to quickly jump into competitive play will need to invest either time or money.
As a initial backer of the kickstarter campaign - I have personally logged hundreds of hours into Hex; please don't be offput by my paltry amount of played time.

TCG/RPG Concoction Hex is a fantastic TCG Hybrid that wonderfully blends RPG and MMO mechanics into a TCG experience that is truly unique.  Many of the concepts delivered by the game truly push the envelope on what a digital TCG is capable of.  While traditional paper TCGs are held back by the logistics of real-world constraints, Hex is constantly innovating on what being a digital game is all about.  A card might secretly show you your opponent's hand without them knowing, a card might constantly generate spirits to fill your deck, or a card could create a random card out of thin-air; all things that are cumbersome or impossible to do in a traditional paper TCG.

The RPG elements of the game manifest themselves in a way that makes playing a joy.  In the beginning of the PvE campaign, players are required to create a new character that contains several RPG tropes.  Characters gain levels, earn talents, unlock abilities, and earn equipment which can be used to boost the power of their cards and deck.  Players progress through a map encountering different characters and challenges that put their skills to the test.  While there is a general storyline to be followed, the map has several opportunities for players to explore off the beaten path" with many optional challenges and dangers to be conquered.  Defeating encounters rewards the player with Gold (Hex's free to play currency)

reviewText:
Solid. A fun card game that will be very familiar to anyone familiar with MTG.

A lot of the mechanics are fairly unique and would only work well with a PC version of a card game - the art is wildly varied and pretty fun to look at. The decks feel familiar with regards to color, but also do have their own bits of nuance.

Most of all, though, I personally love the addition of a 'character' atop it all - complete with talents and equipment that affect your cards, troops, etc. Clerics are biased towards blessings and buffs, Mages are big on actions/instants, and Warriors bolster troops nicely.

There's also a seemingly pretty robust single player campaign, which rewards you with cards and boosters as you go along - and they don't appear to be totally static as far as what you get.

My only complaint is some of the UI/click actions are a hint delayed feeling and sluggish, but that's really it. Again, the neat mechanics are what make it for me - stacking buffs to the next card of a certain type you draw, cards that scoot up in your deck as turns pass, creation of 'random' cards (any card, not just ones you own), etc.

There's also a nuance in their resource system - it's essentially like MTG with one big difference. In Hex, cards just have a flat cost, i.e. 4 'resource', much like MTG. In MTG however, you might need a total of 3, but two had to be blue. In Hex, you may only have gotten two blue 'resources', but all your resource is lumped into an overall pool, and the colors add a 'threshold.'

Meaning that if you had gotten 2 blue and 5 white, you'd have a total of 7 resource, with a 5 threshold on white and a 2 threshold on blue. As such, you can cast two cards that cost 3 each, even if both require 2 blue, because you meet the 'threshold' amount for those cards. It's a subtle difference but it makes decks a lot friendlier to multicolor and you don't end up getting cornered by needing one more of a color or another as desperately. Most cards I've seen only need one or two threshold, so a multicolor deck can easily squeeze by with just one or two of a resource with a bit of bad luck far longer than you could in MTG!

All in all very fun, great art, lots of interesting mechanics. Solid recommend in my opinion!

reviewText:
TLDR: I love it, give it a shot.

Overview:
Hex, is a wonderfully deep and occasionally frustration inducing card game from Cryptozoic, a company well versed in card and board games. It attempts to merge the trappings of an MMORPG with the infinite expansion of a TCG, and it is mostly successful. In the game’s current state, the MMO aspect is quite weak, while the TCG gameplay is quite strong. By being a digital only game, HEX can break some of the genre tropes and do crazy things like seeding an opponent’s deck with spiders that fight for you when drawn, or providing a small percentage chance that a card in your deck will enter the battlefield upon gaining health. Each set expansion has only made the gameplay more interesting and increased the creativity of the digital only aspect of the game.

The MMORPG Aspect:
What distinguishes HEX from other online TCGs is the MMORPG portion of its game. While HEX is an excellent RPG, the MMO aspect is lacking. There is no required player interaction, and no way to see other players within the world itself. The campaign feels like a strong single player RPG, but currently has no way for players to have any meaningful interaction beyond strategy discussions and card trading. You cannot see where are players are in the world, and all chat is done through a single chat channel, or through private conversations between friends. For an MMO it feels lonely.
That being said, the RPG aspect is great! The player travels through the world on a node based map, with each node being either a combat/story encounter or a town or dungeon. Towns serve little purpose, other than a place to gather and turn in quests. Dungeons are repeatable zones with their own unique maps and rewards for completion. Rewards for encounters and dungeons range from gold (usable on the auction house to purchase new cards) to new cards and equipment. Equipment is what truly sets HEX apart from the competition in terms of TCGs. Each piece of equipment affects a different card and can drastically change how it is used in combat. Equipment can only be used in the RPG portion of the game, and has no effect in PVP, as it would destabilize the careful balance going on there.

The TCG Aspect:
Anyone familiar with Magic, or the now defunct WoW TCG (not Hearthstone), will be able to immediately pickup HEX and grasp the core concepts. Players play resource cards to afford bigger and better cards until one player is crushed by the strength of the other. In HEX, each player takes on the role of a Champion from the greater HEX lore, each of which has their own unique special ability which can be triggered when certain conditions are met (similar to Hearthstone). Thus, a deck can be built around a specific champion, or a champion can be chosen to compliment a deck composition.
Where things get really interesting are in the different abilities that cards can have. Health stealing, instant attacking, and early striking are genre staples, but HEX introduces numerous abilities that are only really manageable in a computer run TCG. Escalation, the newest ability doubles a card’s printed numerical value (including its cost) but only while the card is still in hand. Tunneling allows a card to be placed on the field for a reduced cost, but with a timer until it is revealed and usable. My favorite abilities revolve around providing a stat boost to all cards of a specific type regardless of where they are located, in my hand, deck, graveyard, or field. This allows me to buff up cards that I have yet to play or even draw, allowing for a big surprise when I finally play a low cost troop with numerous buffs that result in a heavy hitter.

The PVP Aspect:
I have not taken the deep dive into the PVP aspect of the game, beyond some friendly matches against friends and a couple of tournaments. There are numerous way to play PVP and plenty of rewards for playing. It is common to get crushed by players who have spent hundreds of dollars on their decks, and that is the aspect which has kept me out of the TCG scene up until this point. For me, there is enough content, and opportunity to earn free cards in the RPG portion of the game, that I don’t need to rely on PVP.

Pros:
+ Strong RPG gameplay
+ Tough puzzles in the RPG (Require creative deck building)
+ Class and Race combos
+ Variety of gameplay styles
+ Easy to play completely free (though with a grind)
+ More content incoming
+ Encourages alt characters

Cons:
- Weak MMO implementation
- Pay to win PVP
- Class imbalance (Mage = hard mode, Cleric = easy mode)
- No guild system (Promised, but not yet implemented)
- No player interaction required (Promised, but not yet implemented)
- PVE can be a grind

reviewText:
An exelent TCG, a bit reminiscent of MTG but with its own quirks. The game fully use it's virtual component to play with cards in ways physical cards cant, such as manipulating core cards in game, decks composition and effects. For instance you can place booby traps inside your enemy deck, increase cost of cards in his hands, lower stats of cards in his deck, etc.

The game offer a solid pvp side, which i am mostly unfamiliar with, but there are such things as drafts and tournaments.

The game also offer a (still in development but the first zone is out) PVE campaign. Some fight feels more like puzzle solving, since you may have to adapt your cards to fit the situation. in others you gotta deal with the situation using your race/class and elements best you can. For instance, an elf gain more hp and increased chances for dust drops from dungeon and other classes have more dungeon lives or are stronger on the last/first lives. The adition of classes and hero to chaperon your deck is also a good way to add additional interactions without making the game much more complex.

Equipment serve to empower cards, a gauntlet effect could be someshing like ' your fireballs cost -1 or deal +2 damage or cause enemies to lose -1 attack, etc. More complex effects are also present, such as causing the equipped card to revert itself after a condition is presented.

The game offer an auction house where pretty much everything can be bought with gold, that is acquired in pvp vs AI arena and in campaign, and with platinum which is the real money currency.

Platinum can also be used to buy custom card skins and boosters (campaign also reward zone boosters, which can be sold and oppened)

Deckbuilding is available (similar to mtg), there are already enough cards to see multiple deck types (and heroes) and cards being used in PVP and PVE.

All in all it is a solid game, the makers like it, so does the players, and it is free!

-Lost

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about this game. On one hand it is one of the best TCG on the market. It's complex, fun, challenging and has a (mostly) helpful and dedicated community.

On the other hand it has many problems. Server issues on the steam release, Steep and unforgiving learning curve, unfinnished and unrefined PVE and a PvP that has far too many barriers for entry.

Let's start with the pvp and the barriars you'll face to enter. To be blunt, it costs money to participate in any meaningful pvp. Although this is standard practice in the TCG world, in the world of video games this will bewilder people and put many new players trying pvp particularly when they find that the skill gap between newer players and the players that are obviously dedicated to Hex and TCG's in general is huge. The strange thing is they don't seem to realise how good they are at the game. Even a experienced Magic card player like myself was pushed hard in contructed. Nevertheless as a digital card game trying to simulate the environment of real world TCG with it's rules and market place has left the game with an identity crises of being a F2P video game with a pay to participate TCG model.

However, paradoxically PVP is where the game truly shines. If you are an experienced TCGer I could not reccomend this game enough even if it is just to try. The game itself is reminiscent of MtG but with a few twists in the mechanics. Although at times it can get to obsurd levels with over 100 cards on the table in one of my games, it is great fun.

As for PVE. It's fairly basic although people complain about the difficulty, and in truth there are difficulty spikes all over the place, with practice and some research even f2p players can complete the campaign. However, I would not reccomend this game for players that are new to TCGs. It simply does not do a good job of teaching new players the game and does not open an easy gateway for new players to introduce themselves to PVP. To be frank, without a large playerbase with large population of low skilled players, this game will always struggle retain players trying to get into Hex.

But if you have a will of iron and a willing to improve yourself I would reccomend this game. If not, then this is definetely not the game for you.

reviewText:
HEADS UP:
-The free to play portion of this game is a lot a like a starter deck, meant to get you introduced to the rules and let you know if you like the game, however eventually you'll want to spend money to add cards and build on your deck or go play in an official tourney.

-A lof of complaints seem to be coming from people that dont play physical TCGs or are just getting into the TCG genre. Anyone that is even slightly familiar with any big TCGs knows that it costs money for new packs and to play in offical tourneys and drafts (anyone that has gone to a single Friday Night Magic knows this). This is the paid content that keeps this game alive and generates new content. Again, this isnt new to anyone thats ever played a physical TCG.

-The only pay to play portion of this game is to buy brand new packs and participate in offical tourneys, which is comparable or even less than playing a standard draft or tourney in your local shop. As a reward for participating in theses tourneys you often get your money back in the form of packs rewarded based off how well you did.

-Everything else is free. Duels, campaigns, dungeons, frost ring arena (a type of gauntlet where you duel progressively harder decks),  Unoffical tourneys (there are several websites dedicated to these and offer some very nice prizes), you can buy cards, mercenaries, equipment, chests, and even second hand unopened packs, all for the free in game currency you get for just playing.

-You can play this game for free and have an excellent time doing it, using the in game gold you earn to buy cards and second hand unoppened packs to build awesome decks off the AH. However you can pay for some Plat and have it go even further, individual cards are quite cheap but should you choose so, this hobby can cost you just as much as Magic should you decide to compete in drafts, and tourneys just like at a Friday Night Magic.

The game itself is without a doubt best and most thought out TCG out there, counting both its digital and physical competition. It has rewarding mechanics, a great community, amazing art and borrows enough from MTG to feel familiar but improves on so much to make it its own thing. For a more indepth review there are plenty better ones, and I would recommend watching some duels to really get the feel of it but I wanted to help clear any confusion for those that may not be familiar with how large/successful TCGs work.

This game is out but only has a fraction of its planned content, it will get much better in time with additional formats like double headed dragon, anything goes (where you can use your pve cards against eachother),  the inclusion of crafting, clans, clan decks, clan pvp, raids and a much larger pve campaign.

Beta player here...
I'm a lazy ♥♥♥ and Veers nicely wrote what i could say (just replace heartstone with DoC or  solforge) so i'll quote him :)


TL;DR: I have hundreds of hours on the Magic Duels series and Hearthstone - I uninstalled both shortly after discovering HEX and haven't looked back. It's free - try it!

HEX is a digital trading card game done right, embracing digital mechanics and having robust tournament support. PvE modes are fun, rewarding, and accessible, but expect a significant grind to play PvP as a F2Player.

Highs:
- Magic the Gathering (MTG) players already know the rules
- Unlike MTG's digital offerings, HEX embraces mechanics that are only possible with digital cards
- Unlike Hearthstone, HEX is a complex game with considerable interaction between players
- Robust tournament support, including synchronous Limited that fires regularly (<hourly) and asynchronous Sealed
- The RPG campaign is unlike anything I've played before (working on my 6th clear atm...)
- Best community I've ever seen!
- Devs clearly love the game and have a number of awesome features in the works
- All cards (and other items/currency) are easily tradable to other players

Lows:
- Auction house is tedious to use - I tend to stick to trade chat" transactions
- Takes about 10h to grind a draft entry fee as a beginner - I'd recommend spending $10 on drafts to jump-start your collection and speed up the grind"

reviewText:
This is essentially Magic: The Gathering with a few additional mechanics that wouldn't be easily implemented in a physical format card game. The game flow is almost exactly the same as MTG with the major differences being:

- Mana (gems in Hex) have a smoother curve overall and there is less management of it.
- There are heroes similar to what you have in Hearthstone with unique abilities, health totals and so forth.

Aside from that you are more or less playing Magic. Even the gem colors/strategies are copied from Magic so if you like to play Red/White Aggro in MTG then R/W Aggro is going to be pretty damn similar in Hex. Blue control? Yep, it's here. All of the general tendencies and basic strategies are very similar across both games.

Now, I like MTG. I played it for years. The MTGO client has always been a bit... special and it definitely isn't as beginner friendly as Hex because there is single player campaign mode. Even the standalone annual MTG games can't compare to the campaign mode in Hex. That said, Hex doesn't have that great of a client either. It's slow and not particularly responsive. The store is clunky and the auction/marketplace is downright painful to use.

Hex also lacks in the format department in comparison to MTG, so don't expect a lot of options outside of basic drafting and constructed. You won't see anything like EDH in Hex, at least not yet.

To sum up: Do you like Magic: The Gathering? Yes? Then you will like Hex. It's cheaper and the client is slightly better. No? Move along and give SolForge or Hearthstone a try. (Definitely try SolForge. It's a great game and it plays FAST.)

reviewText:
TCG? CHECK! RPG? YUP! MMO? Si!

This game is straight fun! This is a Trading Card Game, with a bunch of twists. Did you play any card games as a kid? Pokemon, YuGiHo, Duel Master, Harry Potter, Magic, the list goes on and if you did I would highly recommend giving this game a try. The best way to describe this game is a deeper, more fun hearthstone, BUT WITH TRADING! Seriously, no more getting a legendary for a class you don't play and having to destroy it for a 1/4th of its value! Another description would be a cheaper Magic the Gathering (2$ booster packs v. 4$ packs), with an online version that doesn't make you want to pull your hair out.

What makes this game unique????

Auction house! - from rages to riches, sell/trade using gold (farmable currancy) and plat (paid currency)

Totally free to play viable! - At first it may not seem like it, but this game is very free to play friendly. It has a deeeeep PVE campaign and arena (which allows you to earn gold). What can you do with gold? Buy stuff on the AH, trade gold directly with other players for plat, and buy packs to open or enter tournaments! Why will paying players want your gold?  Simple, because gold has real value for paid players. Everytime you open a pack you get your 17 cards, and a chest which you can use gold to spin (which is basically a slot machine that can upgrade your chest to another rarity or give you other cool rewards like card sleeves or other cards!

A card game with a story... - Seriously, it is well written and fun to play while teaching you how to play the game even if you are a complete noob! When I started playing I just clicked through the text because I normally don't card about story for games I play, I actually restarted when I figured out how cool and funny the story is.

RPG aspects? - YUP! You can level up your PVE character and put equipment on which dramatically changes cards and can take crap cards to amazing cards! Oh and all the equipment is sellable and buyable on the AH.


A few things to note
---- There are PVE only cards, which at first I thought was kind of lame but I it allows PVE to have overpowered/fun cards without damaging PVP balance.
---- There have been some server errors when the game launched on steam. These have been resolved, and I haven't had since day 1.

reviewText:
Seing that the game got a lot of negative feedback thanks to a rough start, i have to chime in:
Now, i backed the game on Kickstarter, for a lot actually, and i'm still missing some features that made me back in the first place (Guilds, more PvE, Raids and the actual MMO aspect). Nevertheless the game at this point is very solid and in my opinion one of the best F2P Games. Now, you might have a different opinion what a good F2P game is, but for me its one where the developers actually can make money and the players and especially new players don't feel like playing a P2W game.
Now hex is a card game, and therefore you are only as good as your cards, and cards cost money. But hex gets around that by nailing the TCG aspect perfectly. You can buy/trade/sell your cards, your items and your packs, something i have never seen in a CCG/TCG game before. Blizzard for example would never let you trade your unwanted cards for free to other players. Hex does that!
You can grind for gold, buy a pack from the AH sell it for plat and ... BOOM ... you never spend a dime but got the actually real world money currency in the game, and do with it what you want (pay the entry fee to a tournament for example)

So in short: The game still misses a lot of features that were promised, but they went with something that allows them to build a community and especially create a business model, and i respect that. reviewText:
Hex will occasionally frustrate the hell out of you.  If you walk away from the game before fully exploring it due to that frustration, you’ll be missing out on one of the best video game / TCG experiences in your lifetime.

Once you ‘get it’ you’ll find yourself coming back to this game over the years more than any other game in your library.  I promise.  It’s that good.  Better even.

For those that wave this game off as an MTG clone, they have not really explored it to its full potential.  Yes, the overarching mechanics are very similar and it may take you some time to spot the differences, but once you do, oh boy, the game opens up to you in ways that no other TCG can, MTG included.  One thing to note though, beyond the PvE portion, if you approach this game as a TCG only, it can bankrupt you in boosters just like MTG, so approach that aspect of the game with caution if you have a ‘I must collect everything’ mentality.

There have been some that have gotten full sets without spending a dime on skill alone but for most people if you want to experience the thrill of PvP tournaments with prizes against some of the friendliest competitors around, you’ll probably have to spend about 5 to 7 USD or more per tournament.  I did not approach this game as a PvP player, but I am now addicted to PvP play (even though I stink) and in my many losses I have never walked away without thinking it isn’t money well spent (for most tournaments you end up with a lot of valuable tradable cards even when losing).

Then there is PvE which is just beginning (there is currently about 10-15 hours of content, with hundreds of more hours to come over the next few years) and that requires no money at all – as someone with a full collection of the first three sets, I find the experience a lot more fun not relying on my card library and using a PvE character’s free card pool.  I’ve read some reviews that say it takes too long to grind for cards, but all of those reviews seem to be from people grinding to enter the completely separate PvP tournaments which start at 5 to 7 USD, so yeah, it’ll take you a bit to make money out of thin air.

You’ll hear some people complain that there are PvE battles that are ‘too difficult’ – and for many people, yeah, they are right.  None of those battles are required to progress through the PvE campaign and all of them can be won without purchasing any cards or boosters and are designed to test your mettle and rely on a bit of luck; if you do win them, you can walk away with some valuable prizes you can turn around on the Auction House or keep in your collection to excel at the next PvE campaign release.

Onto the more negative part of this review, if you do get hooked to the game I’d suggest you ignore all of the hype for the upcoming features they say are coming beyond the card set and PvE campaign releases (and PvE campaigns and PvP card set releases are still far from consistent).  Those crazy features?  Crazy awesome!  And you’ll drive yourself mad if you learn about them because it’ll sound like those features are just around the corner but who in the hell knows when they’ll actually have time to code them into the game.  Yes, they are working on them, yes, they have shown steady progress and dedication on those features, but the game stands on its own without them and you’ll be better off being surprised when they do eventually come rather than be disappointed when a feature date is missed.  The company cares about the community but gets too caught up in its own hype and consistently misses their deadlines.  They have shown, however, that they listen to the community and have reversed more than a few poor decisions based upon the active player base.  They really seem to care first and foremost in producing a ‘fun experience’ for the players rather than raking in cash.

And man oh man is the experience fun; give it some time and patience you will be rewarded.

reviewText:
I've been playing since the alpha. If this is the first time you've seen this game, you're in for a treat. I think one of the most prohibitive things about TCGs is the cost and accessibility of getting to play them in the first place. Perhaps you don't live near a gaming store that hosts things like friday night magic. Perhaps you don't really have the money to drop on expensive booster packs in physical tcgs.

The great thing about HEX is it addresses all those things. Booster packs (bought straight from gameforge, not from steam) are at most 2 dollars each, much cheaper than any physical tcg, with a minimum of 15 cards per pack. Plus, a great bonus of playing online is a bit hidden from view, but the math checks out:

DONT OPEN YOUR BOOSTER PACKS DIRECTLY. Instead, participate in tournaments. Sometimes you'll win some good prizes, other times you'll lose, but that's okay. The entrance fee to a competitive draft tournament in hex, for example, is 3 packs (600 plat) and 100 platinum for a total of 700 platinum (it's a little less than that if you buy packs on the auction house, though). So, we now have 8 people contributing 100 extra plat towards prize money, that's 800 plat total, or 4 packs worth. Well, the prize pool is actually a total of 12 packs, so you'll have a better than 50% chance to walk away with more cards than the plat value you contributed, all in the name of a good tournament!

And who knows, maybe you'll do well enough to pay for your next tournament for free! Good play and good deck design is well rewarded in hex.

So go put away your hearthstone cards, HEX is the digital TCG of champions!

And hey, if pvp isn't your thing, multi-user co-op dungeons and raids are coming!

reviewText:
What do you get when you combine the best aspects of Magic: The Gathering (resource management and combat) and Hearthstone (Hero powers) and excellent PvE content for those who prefer single player?
You get Hex: Shards of Fate!

I'm gonna keep this simple and cut straight to the chase. I am no veteran of card games, nor am I one of the die hard fans who backed this game on the kickstarter about 3 years ago. So if you want a more in depth perspective and backstory on development, feel free to ask someone from the community. They are remarkably kind and helpful.

This game is beautifully constructed. Lots of thought and effort went into building the lore, the PvE battles and cards. It brings new ideas into the card game genre, such as the Hero Equipment concept. You equip your champion with items that will enhance certain cards in your deck, allowing for lots of variation in deck building and (in theory) much more options than other card games.

In single player Campaign mode, you get to create your own champion, combining one of 8 races and 3 classes. There are 2 factions with 4 races each, and they all take place in the same world map with minor variation in events and location depending on which race you choose. The campaign is where you acquire most of your basic cards to use later in PvP if you wish to do so, although the game never pressures you to go for PvP.
You can just single player all day long and have fun by yourself.

However, as you progress through the campaign, you begin to realize that the cards you get from campaign rewards do not match the steep dificulty curve of the coming battles. The game throws everything in the kitchen sink at you, with enemy champions using clearly overpowered abilities and troops that require very specific card combinations and synergies to be countered. It's like if your boss at work tells you to fix this copy machine" but does not give you the tools or finance you need to fix it.

Not only do you need more powerful cards to progress

The only way to make actual progress through the campaign is to participate in the game's built in economy and start buying the advanced cards that synergize well with each other. And this is where the grind aspect becomes truly monstrous in proportion.

The community has even created a "guide" for new players advising them on how to grind the campaign and arena properly and progress through the game. I am not even kidding! When I first saw the guide

If you like collectable card games, I cannot reccomend this game enough, seriously go play it there are some great ideas in play here.

If you don't like collectable card games, I can't say you are going to like this but it might have something for you, maybe just try the PvE campaign.

If you have never played a collectable card game, this might be a really good one to try, the PVE campaign is pretty good at easing you into things, I don't know if going straight to PvP would be a good idea though the decks there are really ingenious.

Also having played this on and off over several years the game is really growing wonderfully. I think they picked a good spot to do the steam release. However there are a few interface things which need more polish.

In particular in the PvE campaign there are rules for how many cards of a given rarity and which colors you can use with a given race/level that is not very clearly shown. This can be frustrating if you like to plan out your decks heavily in advance or have a 'build' you wanted to try straight off the bat.

But that is more a challenge for the experienced CCG player and the filtering of total cards I think could be valuable for a newbie to keep from being overwhelmed by deck building choices.

I would give it a 9/10 as the game still has room for improvement, but it is definitely going in the right direction.

Multiplayer PvE is definitely a long awaited feature that was promised and has not yet been released, but from a technical perspective I can definitely see why it's been delayed.

reviewText:
Recommended if..
*Card games like magic or hearthstone aren't a complete turn off
*You don't mind facing computer opponents (PVE)
*You'll suffer through a crappy tutorial and first dungeon (maybe an hour of play) before passing judgment

The tutorial really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off, you basically click and do exactly what it tells you to fight after fight. The game makes a claim that it's different than other games, but it's not at all. Players of hearthstone or magic the gathering will feel right at home. You also don't really get to fiddle with much until you complete the first dungeon. The game doesn't tell you this, and you're left wondering, am I stuck with these cards, or how do I change them? But after the first dungeon, the fun begins.

I can only recommend this game if you either don't mind paying for packs for virtual cards, OR you don't mind playing against computer opponents. This game offers a ton of PVE content. You get to select a faction, a race, and a class. There are skills to use, you level up, and each choice in customization has an effect on your game (minus gender which is purely cosmetic). The campaign is completely free, and a blast to play. It's challenging, but not overly so. You'll earn gold and cards along the way which have value. A truly dedicated player could theoretically play enough PVE content to be effective in PVP, but prepare for a long road.

At this point, the in game ads are nearly non exsistant, there's no energy system, the classes and races are NOT restricted to paying customers. There is a currency you can buy (platinum) and a currency you earn playing the game (gold). It is not impossibly hard to trade gold, or cards you've acquired for free for platinum. I don't think it's fair to reasonably expect anything more from a free to play game. It's a shame there needs to be a premium currency at all, but it's understandably necessary.

I really love the art in this game, and the races they feel somewhat unique/creative. The sound is nice and peaceful, the backgrounds and cards are varied enough to not get bored too easily. The only thing lacking is the animation, it is a card game, so what do you expect? I can't fault the animation, it does what it needs to. It's just the art on the cards is so neat, you want to experience more of the world and characters than just the still images.

The biggest flaw is the PVP, which you have a significant advantage if you have good cards. Not all cards are created equal. Getting a deck to a competitive state will take an investment, be it monetary or time. But you can find many hours of enjoyment foregoing PVP entirely.

reviewText:
(There seems to be a limit to the length of a Steam review. I did not know that. Please see the comment section for parts II - VI)

************************
PART I
************************

Hi, friend. Welcome. You are clearly interested in TCGs, or card-based games in general, so let me tell you a bit about HEX.

First of all, this game has only been on Steam for a few days, but I have been playing since 2013, when the game was in the Alpha stage, so my hours played are closer to 500–1000. And that is a conservative estimate. So I believe I am qualified to tell you a bit about this game.

Now, I am going to do this a bit differently. I will not try to cater to all players in general. I will speak directly to the players who are like me, because I would want to know about this game as soon as possible, and I will emphasize the points that made me fall in love with the game. Subsequently, this review will be long, because I would not mind reading a long well-written review myself, and I would want to know about all these features I will soon write about. Additional caveat: if you are not willing to truly immerse yourself in the game and properly learn all its myriad features and possibilities, this game might not be for you. This is not a very casual game. This is for true gamers who love complex mechanics and enjoy the incredible freedom HEX provides for the innovative player. Still here? Great! Let us jump right in.

Have you always been looking for that one card-based game that would finally have a good single-player campaign, where you can collect cards simply by playing? And better yet, the cards you can collect are not limited in any way, so you can actually collect every single card in the game. Are you tired of all these “campaigns” in card games, where the solo content is simply a series of text boxes? Are you fed up that you can only complete them once, and then you are pretty much forced to play PvP if you want any further rewards? Why do card games never really build a world where you can adventure, like in an RPG? You might still remember Shandalar (nod to older gamers), where you could actually walk around on the world map, do quests and buy cards from taverns. Why is that not ever attempted anymore?  Well, your search is finally over. Enter HEX, the most ambitious card-based game that has ever existed.

First of all, I would strongly recommend you watch the video on the Store page, where you can see this strange bearded guy with glasses. That strange bearded guy is one of the biggest reasons you should invest your time in this game. Let him tell you about it himself. I will come back to this point a little later. Let us explore the game first.

HEX has two distinct sides. PvE and PvP. I will talk a bit about the PvP in the end, but quite frankly, that is an experience many other games provide as well. There are plenty of reviews out there that concentrate on the competitive side of HEX. I am not a competitive person, so I will mostly talk about how you can enjoy HEX without PvP. That is what drew me to the game, and if you are like me, that is the only thing you want to hear about.

HEX has well over a thousand cards (I do not know the exact number, but it might be thousands at this point). There is a robust Card Manager that lets you combine them however you wish to make decks, and let me tell you, you can make some pretty fun decks. I have a deck that copies and replicates troops named Time Bug that aims to give myself infinite turns with the card’s ability. I have an Insect deck that only has disgusting crawlies. I have a life gain deck that aims to win via getting as much health as possible. I have a spider deck that will bury my opponent in eggs that actually go into your opponent’s deck (not possible in any non-digital TCG). I have a burrowing deck, where all the troops go underground and dig themselves up at the exact right moment to kill my opponent (again, only possible in a digital environment). All the decks play completely differently, and all are incredibly fun. I am constantly coming up with new deck ideas. If you enjoy deck-building, HEX is heaven. There is no limit to the number of decks you can create, and I currently have approximately 112 decks. All completely different. Are you starting to see the scope of this thing?

There is an entire Campaign where you walk on the world map. You can choose your path and do quests and side quests and get to know the world and lore. You can delve into a dungeon, which are longer, story-driven locations with better loot. You actually create a character and choose a race and class, and every class has their own talent tree, like in a real RPG. These talents in turn change the way you play the encounters or how you build your deck. There are not many classes to choose from yet, but every PvE patch will add more content. That is what makes it so exciting. This journey will never end, as there will constantly be more places and characters to explore. Just like in an MMORPG. Speaking of MMOs, there will eventually be co-operative raids, where you will take on huge bosses with two of your friends in a 3-against-1 scenario. These will naturally drop the most epic loot. There will be guilds as well, with guild banks, where you can presumably loan some cards from other members of your guild for that one particularly nasty encounter.

But wait, there is more. You can also collect equipment for you cards. Think about that for a second. You can equip your hero like in an RPG. Equipment can drastically change what a card does, which in turn changes how you play with the deck. Guess what, your possibilities just doubled. There are hundreds of pieces of equipment in the game, and even I have not come close to testing them all yet. In fact, every single card will eventually have 1–2 equipment. That is a mind-boggling amount of customizability. Some of them do really wacky things. Some of them are a great help against a particular boss for example. I have won encounters simply by changing some of the equipment in my current deck. You can find equipment during your adventures as loot, or you can get them from chests after opening packs. Wait, what?

Yes. Every time you open a pack, you will get a treasure chest as an additional reward. Just for opening a pack. These are of random rarity, and can range from common to legendary. The chests can contain equipment or cards, including rarer alternative art cards, which you can either keep or sell to buy something else you want. You might not want to open a chest immediately though. You see, there is one more additional level of rewards added to the pack opening experience. You can spin your chests with in-game earnable currency before opening them. Spinning yields some of the best rewards in the entire game. Or you can just save your gold and open the chest right away. The choice is yours.

Then there are Primal packs and chests. Every time you purchase a pack from the in-game store, there is a possibility that it will generate a Primal Pack. These are insane packs that only contain rares and legendaries. Oh, by the way, did I mention that a HEX pack has 17 cards, so you get more cards per pack than in any other card game I know of. Primal Chests can only be obtained by spinning a chest and getting an upgrade. These chests contain some of the most sought-after rewards in the game, like extremely rare sleeves for your decks.

reviewText:
This game is pretty much a revamped magic the gathering for the computer.   There are only mediocre or bad MTG games (compared to the card game itself) but this has so far lived up to a fair expectation.  The best part is, with how they did it, it will be pretty easy for them to keep adding cards and keep the game running for a long time.   Unfortunately, I do feel paying as much as they are asking for the cards is a bit pricey.  Sure, you can earn gold and packs and get cards through grinding, but they are borderline greedy with their pricing.

Overall, I give the game a 7/10 for the PVE side for the following reasons:
-Decent art
-great copy of Magic the Gathering, making it VERY easy to learn
-Plenty to do right from the start.
-Nice little leveling system for those of us that have to progress in games.
-plenty of cards so you will see a lot of different combos when playing

The Bad
-Expensive product if you choose to pay.
-A 'VIP system' which gives you minor rewards and also gives you discounts on other things, which encourages you to buy even more than you need to
-Poor preperation for steam.  Servers went down today, so they will get some negative reviews for that.
-Campaign could still use some touch ups, nothing big, just a bunch of little things.

The game is free, and I highly suggest trying it if you miss playing Magic the Gathering since the game is free.

reviewText:
I kickstarted the game in 2013 and played this since the Alpha.

I really like the deep strategic and tactical nature of a real TCG brought into the digital world. Hex offers an amazing amount of cards in soon 4 PVP Sets (over 1000 cards). The core gameplay parts and the card design (gameplay and artwise) is really great and you can see that people experience in developing TCG game are at work. All Sets played really great in Limited (Drafts/Sealed) as in Constructed. I am looking forward to Set 4 launch in the end of April.

Sure Hex has many rough edges, but the core game is really solid and with every release the game gets more polished and more features. Yes, they did take their time to deliver all the promised features, but its an amazing game that only gets better in the next years.

pro:
-real TCG
-deep gameplay
-lots of cards with amzing art
-rich PVE experience with character development (this is also the F2P part)
-the game embraces its digital nature
-many exciting features in the future
-super nice community
-allows to export data from the game to third party tools which allows awesome stuff
-100.000$ esport tournament happened this year and will happen in the future

cons:
-the game doesnt explain to new player how all the f2p aspects come together
-long waiting times for promised features (but this will probably speed up, now that all the foundations are in place)
-still problems for some people with crashes
-some places still need a lot of polish

reviewText:
I have been playing Hex: Shards of Fate since alpha and haven't stopped enjoying it since. I am a father and now play games casually, unlike when I was in college and could play days on end. This game really makes me wish I was back in those days! This game spoke to me because of the ability to have a variety of options to play this game. I have always enjoyed collectable card games but never had anyone to really play with, so they always fell to the wayside (Magic, Star Wars, Pokemon, Warcraft). When Magic went online, I just couldn't get back into the game like I had once before, feeling it would just take too much time to learn the online mechanics. Hex felt streamlined and I was able to get right into the game without even going through the tutorial.
I liked that it also added in a PvE element into the game. I have always enjoyed PvE in games more than PvP, since I can play at my own pace that way, but I have actually enjoyed the PvP in Hex just as much, and sometimes more, than the PvE. I like the challenge is provides when facing an opponenet, the complexity of the interactions between the cards and the dynamic gameplay that it presents. In PvE and PvP, there are always differnt ways of approaching your opponent and Hex sets it up for you to do so.
There is always an occasional frustration when things just don't go your way, but while I may not like it at the time, I always reflect that it is not always the way it goes, making it realistic in my mind. Makes me enjoy the times I do best an opponent and be able to share a good win with a community member.
The community itself is amazing as well and helps make the game even more enjoyable. You have a lot of helpful players out there who offer advice and tips for playing. I relearned my TCG mechanics and lingo from streamers and learned how passionate people were about the game, like myself.
I see myself playing this game for years to come and looking forward to all the incoming content for the game. If you like to play any games with cards, you will surely enjoy this one.

reviewText: Been playing Hex off and on since late Alpha. While Hex has had problems sticking to a release schedule for new sets and PvE content, it can still be a heck of a lot of fun. They don't do themselves any favors yet referring to this as a free-to-play title, since the most fun can be had playing the quite affordable PvP tournaments. Draft tournaments are my favorite, and they're quite competitively priced, compared to other offerings on the market. When it came out, Hex was fairly compared quite often to Magic: The Gathering, but there are a fair number of differences that become apparent the more you play, and with the release of each passing set, it continues to mature into its own distinctive entity. At this point, I say it's no more similar to MtG than, say, Call of Duty is to Doom.

reviewText:
Hex is taking Magic the Gathering and throwing RPG special sauce all over it. It is a deeper strategy game then Hearthstone. Hex provides a good PVE and PVP experience with mmo style adventure and tournament support.

I have played since Alpha for 100's of hours playing both PVE and PVP.  Players start with 200 cards so you have a lot of options to start playing before having to spend money. As well as earning gold to buy cards on the Auction house. I saw some poor reviews that lambasted HEX as pay to win. I wanted to make sure people understood you get a bunch to start with and play with PVE before you really need to invest any $. Also the claim of PVE harder to force to buy cards shows that people are not using deck builder to update their decks, remember PVE like in hearthstone is more of a puzzle. So you build a deck to solve the puzzle and with the large amount of cards to start you have a lot of choices.

They are still fine tuning the game and releasing their PVE side of the game but the current zone they have released is a taste of building your RPG character and advenuring in their world. character progression as well as gear that boosts specific cards allow players to shift their play style based on their decks and equipment. They also have a taste of their dungeon mechanics that like any MMO will be the key to earning new cards and gear. Their Raid model has not been released yet. Players start with 200 cards so you have a lot of options to start playing before having to spend money. As well as earning gold to buy cards on the Auction house.

PVP as with any MTG store tournament allows players to do anything they could think, as well as thank god supporting draft tourneys.

Their developers are active in listening to the community and have ran their first 100k tourney. On top of that i have yet to not see active team members online going by the NOBLE tags for the game.

Overall for a deeper game then HS I am loving my time with HEX and can't wait for their impromvements.

reviewText:
If you have ever played a TCG before, you probably have the basics down. This game offers that and so much more.
The community (at the time of this writing) is very friendly, helpful when questioned and overall a good bunch of people.

the game itself though is where things shine.

with the release of the PvE Adventure Zone 1, new ways of obtaining Gold and Cards are available. If you play through as one race and class and get to a point where you are a bit stuck, create a new champion and go through a few of them. Just by playing the storyline you are granted packs which contain very useful items. If they aren't useful to you, the Auction House or the Trade Channel can help you find a way to trade/sell it off and get something which pertains to your deck in question.

Once you get some strength, you can then take on the Arena. A gauntlet match of 20 boss fights, lose 3 times, and you have to start over, but every 5 fights you qualify for prizing.

There are three big reasons to do these events. Cards, Equipment, Gold. Not to mention the fact you get to learn a bit more of the game as you go. Got a dungeon your deck doesn't work for yet? fine tune it with different cards. You may have to change things up to win these encounters.

Plenty of replayability, specially with the different race/class types.

The PvP events are a lot of fun to do as well. If you do want to Draft, start off with the 'Swiss' version, this lets you play all the rounds and you can learn a bit more of the cards. Once you are confident, go on to the Competive modes which are single elimination with a bigger payout.

All in all, this game has been a blast to play since the Alpha, I just wish i could play more.

reviewText:
HEX is not finished, but that is a good thing, albeit frustrating at times for those of us that want everything mentioned in the Kickstarter. With what is available right now, it's a completely playable TCG; it's got drafts, sealed, constructed; it has a solid PVE campaign, fully functional auction house, and MMORPG elements (socketable cards, equipment, levels, talents).

HEX is a game that is a dream come true for many of us; a competitive, high quality, TCG where you cards actually have value. I played Magic as a teenager and have been looking for something to bring those good times back, without having to go to a card shop every week. HEX is the answer that many of us have been looking for.

If you just want to play for free, and you aren't willing to grind, go play something else. However you play this game, the community is incredible and if you speak up a bit, I'm sure someone will help you get started.

reviewText:
Deep Strategy
The strategy is very well designed with interesting mechanics and all sorts of clever ways to defeat your opponent.

Many Ways To Play
You can play against the AI (PVE) in a campaign, or arena, or practice matches. Or you can play against other players in various formats that accommodate your play style and time available. Even beginners can be competitive from day one if they play the draft or sealed card formats, where everyone builds their decks with the card packs that are opened before the match.

Offers A Challenge
The PVE is challenging, in a good way. You have to use your wits and improve your deck as you go in order to get through the campaign. The gold you earn can be used in the Auction House to buy more cards. And you get free cards and packs as you progress through the campaign as well.

Great Community
Really friendly and helpful community. One of the best I have ever seen.

Awesome Streamers
There is a really good group of streamers on Twitch that stream HEX all the time. It is a great way to pick up strategies and learn some of the cards. They are welcoming and answer questions.

Good Developer
The developers really know what they are doing. They are a long time developer of TCG games, and it shows with all the cleverness they put into this game.

reviewText:
Bring up the fact that this game is like Magic the Gathering and you will see the chat become a rage... but its nearly identical. This is of course a good thing if you are a fan of Magics mechanics. The game does make use of the fact that it is played over an electronic medium by allowing light card customizing with gem sockets that give your guys buffed effects (so long as you have the mana on board), equipment for versing the AI, and various other effects that simply cannot be done in Magic or physical card games. The game has good graphical polish, with very nice art through out.

In terms of this game being Free to Play? you would probably have better luck in Hearthstone. You could def do very well with out ever spending money in the 1 player modes by slowly grinding gold and purchasing powerful commons and uncommons but don't expect to come out a winner in most PvP matches against powerful constructed decks. Further on the note of 1 player mode, there are still some features missing from the game, and some bugs in the Frost Arena mode (buffs not activating).
Would I reccomend this game? It totally depends on the type of gamer you are and what you expect to get out of it.

reviewText:
TLDR:

Pros

Engaging and replayable
Ambitious scope
Opportunity to make real-world $ from your collection
Fantastic community
Passionate developers (Hex Entertainment - HxE)
Brilliant customer support (Gameforge - GF)
Appeals to a variety of audiences – Role-playing Divas, Multi-player Competition Junkies, Stock Market Profiteers, Slot Machine Addicts and Wannabe Art Connoisseurs
Cons
Inconsistent schedule of content releases
Poses a serious threat to marital bliss

I've been playing since Alpha and have accumulated more than a couple of thousand hours in the game. My wife often accuses me of having an affair with the PC and it's gotten to a stage where she frequently uses it as a tool in domestic negotiations. My two year old son has also figured the best way to get daddy's attention is by pulling the plug.

I am absolutely in love and Hex has become my go-to leisure activity. The easisest way to describe it is, the more time I give it, the more rewarding it becomes. There's so much of variety and replayability, it absolutely STOMPS any other game out there in terms of value. It really is a lifestyle" game.

You have completely F2P PvE content

reviewText:
MTG online with a slightly less terrible UI and PvE elements. It's not F2P unless you spend a lot of time grinding the PvE content and play the auction house, which loads painfully slowly and lacks a lot of functionality.

Gameplay is solid, but like I said it's basically MTG. The only real difference is the mana system. When you play a 'charge' (land), you get a threshold - and certain cards require a number of different colored thresholds but otherwise you can spend any type of 'mana'. The best way I can relate this difference to magic is with an example like this:
1) You have 10 Islands and 2 Forests.
2) You want to play two primeval titans (cost 4GG)
3) In Magic, you wouldn't be able to do this because you only have enough green mana for one.
4) In Hex, you can do this. As long as you have enough mana, you only need to have the two forests (threshold counters).

reviewText:
I've played Hex since the original alpha, and it is definitely in my top 5 games of all time for time spent.  I spend most of my time playing PVE, having built my total investment of around $150 into 10-15 solid decks that I can rotate through, with new ones being created on a regular basis.  At less than 50 cents an hour, that's also probably near the top of my games in terms of value as well.

My PVP experience has been focus on Sealed Gauntlet, which allows me to play a match here or there rather than dedicate the hours needed for a traditional tournament.  It also means that I'm on even ground with everyone else, despite not having many of the most expensive cards.

The most important advice I would give about the game is if you run into difficulty in the campaign, first make sure that you can't just skip that encounter, as there are many optional challenges throughout.  Then, if you really are blocked, start a new character!  The best part about this game is the wide variety of viable decks, and playing as different characters will not only help you improve, but you'll earn cards that you can use on your first character to help them too!

reviewText:
I've been playing Hex for nearly 2 years now and there have been an extremely low amount of days where I have not logged in to play a draft or do some PvE or just play around in the game. Yes the basic gameplay is very similar to MtG but that is what drew me to it. It does so many things right and is a much better digital environment to play in then MtGO ever was. If you enjoy trading card games and are looking for one you can play from the comfort of your own home whenever you have the time to play without having to look for a place to play or people to play with then Hex is for you.

Yes the PvE side of the game allows one to play and enjoy aspects of the game for free. Yes you can grind out gold (the PvE currency) to get PvP items from the AH. No, this is not a Pay to win game... it's a TCG. This is how trading card games work, cards have value because they are rare, and because people want them. If they were common and easy to get or useless and never played then they have no value. The value of a card in a trading card game is dependent on what people are willing to pay for it, this does not make a game pay to win it makes the game an investment. If you want to play a card game PvP but don't like that the rarer cards cost money (Which is how TCGs will always work) then this game is not for you, TCGs are not for you so why are you looking into a TCG?

No, Hearthstone is not a TCG, it's a CCG. In a game where you can not trade your cards your money and time disappear into a black hole of nothingness. Hex is a TCG, which means both your money and time is treated like an investment. As long as people want to buy whats in your collection then your collection will have a monetary value. This is the point of a *trading* card game.
