reviewText:
Disclaimer: I've been a player since alpha, so my opinion is a bit biased.

I've sunk a lot of money into this game as a kickstarter backer because I wanted a digital version that's similar to MTG. Is the core mechanics almost identical to MTG? Of course. You'd be silly to not see the differences.

However, where others see blatant ripoff, I see an homage from people who loved playing MTG growing up and wanted to create a purely digital version of it.

This game is great for people who are familiar with MTG as you'll pick up the core concept really quickly. What sets this game apart is all the items added to this game that make it only viable in a digital space.

Permanently changing cards that persist across all zones? Check.
Inserting traps and spiders into opponent's deck? Check
Stealing cards from opponent's hand and deck and changing the cards so you can play them? Check
Buffing cards in your deck? Check
Doubling the cost and power of cards in your hand? (New to Primal Dawn) Check
PvE Campaign and Frost Arena? Check
Socketing cards with gems to tailor a card to your deck? Check

While that doesn't cover everything that makes this game unique, I feel that it provides plenty of changes that makes it stand out from MTG.

I hope you give this game a fair chance and not write it off as just a MTG clone. It is definitely more than that.

reviewText:
As someone who has only a light history of serious tcg playing, I find Hex to be the type of game I've always been looking for. It fills a nice niche that isn't really in the market atm. At least not with the same quality as Hex has.

Pros:
1. Insanely fun and well designed sets. Limited and constructed are clearly well thought out, and every set brings interesting new mechanics.

2. Unique mechanics only possible in the digital space. Hex sets itself apart by doing crazy things that are not possible in real-life TCGs. Modifying troops, filling an enemies deck with hundeds of spiders, and lots of other fun little things.

3. Possible to play the whole game for free. It will take some work on the part of the player, especially a new one, but I was able to amass a pretty respectable collection in during my time as a f2p player. Constructed pvp is a bit harder to f2p, but then again, Constructed is the most expensive mode in all TCGs.

4. Great Developers and great Community. The devs and players all seem to really care about this game, and they generally are very generous and respectful towards other players.

5. Real value. Hex strives to marry the qualities of real life TCGs and videogames, and as a result, cards in Hex have real money value. (In particular, rares and legendaries, as commons and uncommons are in such high supply.) Cards can be invested in and sold for Platinum (premium currency) or Gold.  If you decide to invest some money in Hex and a few months later, you don't want to play anymore, you can still sell your cards to others through a third party, allowing you to at least get some of your money back (and if you are very lucky and get the timing right, more).

Cons:

1. Starting out can be rough. Between a lack of experience and a small collection, playing the game as a f2p can appear quite daunting. This early phase will require some patience and research to get a good deck for farming the arena, but once it's done, you'll be able to play the game as a true f2p player, especially now that Evo gauntlet is out.

2. Some bugs. They have been getting much better with these, but there are still a few noticable bugs in the game. Nothing extremely bad though.

23/4/2016
========
I finally started enjoying this game once I started building a good deck (thanks to the several players brib... *ahem* I mean giving away free cards to newbies) and started doing a lot better in the arena.

MY PERSONAL suggestion to the new players is DON'T try to finish the campagin if you're new to TCG's. Get a hold of the basics, read guides online and proceed to deck building to run arenas for gold if that's what you're looking for.

Servers are a lot better after yesterdays update. Stutters during AH and deck page scrolling still needs a lot of improvements.

Original Review (Thumbs Down)
=======================
PROS
1) Friendly community
2) Not as P2W as Hearthstone as you can farm gold to buy stuff so much faster. I absolutely love this.
3) Players who prefer the PVE aspects of TCGs would find a lot of things to do here (+make your blood boil too, read cons).

CONS
1) Game is laggy as hell. Why the hell is there a delay and rubberbanding of cards when I'm playing VS AI????? Hearthstone could do it smoothly and I'm playing with over 300ping against other LIVE players.

2) Campaign makes my blood boil. As a new player coming into TCG, my first choice would be to try the campaign out. So why exactly are the AI card draws fixed? The 2nd boss you'll face called Savage Lord plays a 6/4 + 5/3 card on turn 2 EVERY SINGLE TIME. The only way I managed to beat him was by pure RNG luck draw. This is a really great way to turn away new players like myself who are scared away by MTG and Hearthstone but want to try a new TCG. It would be so much better (and fair) if the AI's draw is random.

3) Auction house constantly freezes and takes a long time to load.

Every CON that I've stated above can be fixed and I will change my review once I see it. I really want to like this game  and I've bought the starter pack and spent another 5EUR to support the dev team please don't let me down guys.

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong. The game is good. Very good! It's campaign system ensures that you have ways to get cards and packs free and helps acquaint you with the world Hex is set in. I can compare this with Infinity Wars' campaign (also a free tcg in Steam go check it out.) and Hex has a more expansive campaign that let's you traverse the land, fight foes, conquer dungeons, complete quests and meet likeable NPCs and encounter moments that lets you feel immersed in the world.

Moreso, the battle system is simplistic but familiar. It can be compared with Magic: the gathering, in fact, they play somewhat similarly but Hex has it's own unique charms. The battlefield has never been more scenic and sometimes the settings have special conditions that makes each fight more alive from taming monster cards to add to your collection to saving a transmogrified princess. Every aspect of the game makes it feel more like an RPG than any other TCG out there.

With all that i've said, you may be asking why am I not recommending this game to you? Pretty simple really. Despite all these moments and fun in game, one thing has really been a thorn on my side that really sours my experience and that is the connection stability in this game. The game at times can get REALLY slow making gameplay very cumbersome and really hampers the experience. I like this game so much that I will comeback from time to time trying to muscle my way through this tedious connection problem(and believe me if I didnt love this game, I would just scrap it like any other iTCG I tried), but more often than not I tend to get stuck at loadings, in between turns and phases, and even get disconnected which really bothers my experience. I'll be honest, i don't have the most stable internet and this might be a problem on my part. However despite my download speed reaching more than 0.5 MB/s with ping<50 I still experience these problems and judging from the forum posts on their main site this has been an ongoing issue ever since the Alpha stage. If you can brave this limitations and have, like, the fastest internet out there(or at least more stable than mine) I recommend you check it out and see if yours is stable, otherwise don't bother as you'll just be grinding your teeth trying to get to past the login screen.

Edit: I've decided to recommend this game. My net troubles might just be mine alone. This is a really good card game and once more PvE and campaign content releases, there will be more to do. Everything in game can be obtainable for free and if you think getting premium currency is difficult, it's as simple as offering to trade in your hard earned gold for some platinum. Many folks would rather trade in their plats for gold currency.

reviewText:
Hex is pretty much MtG(o), with some slightly different mechanics. And besides the mana system and WotC cash grab MtG is pretty much the best. Mana system sucks in Hex as well, but hey, boosters are *way* cheaper! Art is pretty great as well, really the only downside is Hex obviously doesn't have nearly as many different cards as MtG does.

For me the main draw of this game were the PvE features, ie campaign and arena. PvP is nice, but constructed in ccgs and tcgs always tends to be a matter of who has the most expensive/powerful cards, while sealed/draft has a price tag on each session.

So, the campaign is.. suprisingly fun. There's only Adventure Zone 1 right now, which is reasonably long with lots of different fights. The AI is pretty awful but the opponents have rather big advantages on their side, so for the most parts fights are interesting. At least if you play with the provided deck and only use PvE rewards to improve that deck, once you start using any significant amount of PvP cards it gets way easier.

Oh yeah, PvE cards. Those are the cards you get as rewards from the campaign quests, adventure packs and such. They're my one huge issue with the campaign, as they tend to be either very vanilla, or silly rng. Going only with the reward cards it's pretty hard to keep any interesting theme in the starter decks. Like the vennen deck, which has a pretty strong spider theme: it's fun, but if you want to stick to the theme it's going to be pretty weak and inconsistent. Unless you get some PvP cards.

Luckily, with some farm/grind it's entirely possible to buy PvP cards with gold you earn during the campaign. Personally I found it pretty distracting having to play auction house while I just wanted to actually play the game, though.

I've been playing mostly f2p so far (bought some plat for a bunch of PvP commons/uncommons mostly), so I haven't had a chance to try drafting. The grind to get enough gold to start drafting is pretty big, but seems doable, and it's possible to go infinite from there if you're good. I'm not, sadly :p

reviewText:
If you like MTG, you'll like Hex.  Don't expect this game to be a F2P MTG, though.  If you want to play competitively, or accumulate valuable rare cards, you will have to spend money (or a lot of time).  But what you are buying can be resold if you quit, much like MTGO (and unlike Hearthstone).  I have friends who have decided they didn't have time to play anymore, and they were able to sell their collection for what they paid for it, though I would say that you usually should expect to take somewhat of a loss in that scenario unless you won a lot of cards through tournaments.

I don't want to say a bunch of things that have already been said, but I will say that some of the negative reviews of this game are just simply false.  You absolutely can beat the campaign (not the challenge missions necessarily) without spending money (or grinding for 100 hrs).  I think people have even done without engaging with the player-run economy (i.e. Auction House), but its far easier if you realize that you can buy some synergistic cards for small amounts of gold (that you get from playing PVE).  Hopefully they will improve the AH and make it more obvious to new players.

There are also some very good negative reviews that point out legitimate flaws with the game, or ways that the game does not meet that player's expectations.  Its certainly not going to be for everyone.  I would encourage people to look at it as a much improved MTGO that also has a PVE component.  Hex is currently not a great F2P game, but its a lot of fun if you are willing to drop $20 to make a decent PVE deck, and even more fun if you are interested in spending some money to play drafts and sealed tournaments.  The F2P components are going to get better with time, as they release more content and tune things up, but for now, solely as a F2P game, I wouldn't recommend it.

Personally, I spend hundreds on MTG back in the day, so getting to play an even better game for far less money is fine by me.  I cashed out my MTG collection and spent 20% of that money on Hex for 100s of hrs of fun (I play this game mostly without using the Steam client, so my actual hours are in the 100-1000 range).  I got this game for PVE, but found I really love playing Limited formats (Draft, Sealed, Gauntlet, etc). The PVE stuff has been horribly delayed, and what is in there now is just the beginning, but I think it has a lot of promise.

tl;dr Try it, keep an open mind, don't focus on being F2P (and use the AH if you do), engage with the community and ask questions, people are generally super nice and helpful

reviewText:
Sometimes a game comes along that manages to deliver what you want with the promise of more to come. For me, the best example of that has been Hex. As a note, I play using the non-steam client so don't worry about my time played.... it's probably closer to 'every hour of the day' :D

So first, the good - genuine F2P model from the PvE campaign. Wonderful draft/gauntlet structure which costs real money but is a lot cheaper than a physical TCG. Great community of streamers, personalities and players who are willing to help out all the time. Creators who have a genuine passion (and credibility from their older work) for this medium. More than anything else, the game is a huge amount of fun.

There are negatives too, important I list them - STEEP learning curve, this will not be the game for everyone. The game is still pretty new so there are a lot of features still to be implimented (guilds, multiplayer PvE are 2 notables that are on the way). Lack of an up to date FAQ can make working out specific interactions a bit of trial and error.

If you've played a TCG in the past (obvious link to Magic but if you've played Netrunner, VTES, the WoW TCG, LOTR you'll notce connections) then you'll get along with game very quickly.

I love this game. Between the game itself and the community (see www.hextcg.com) there's so much to love, and there's only more to come from some of the most talented dvelopers in the digital space!

Cheers for reading.

reviewText:
It's a fun online card game with room for improvements on the F2P side.
Pros:
+Gorgeous card artwork (like MTG)
+Has PVE (Campaign and player vs AI arena)
+Features a RPG-ish campaign that explains the lore behind the card's races and alliances.
+Rich gameplay depth, mechanics, strategy build and card abilities.
+Although most of the tournaments and PVE gameplay requires to pay a fee to enter, there are weekly free-to-join tournaments.
Cons:
-Questionable stability of the campaign server, suffers from constant downtimes.
-The in-game currency from the PVE content (Gold) is nearly useless, without major uses other than seek trade with other players for Platinum.
-Limited access to most of the cards in the game for F2P players. Most of the cards obtained in campaign can't be used for PVP.
-Availability of useful cards and equipment in the Auction House of the game is VERY limited if using Gold for currency. Highly inflated pricings.
-Game is extremely challenging on the PVP side if you don't spend cash to get Platinum and buy Packs/Cards.
-Most tournaments require an entry fee to participate, that leaves F2P players out of most of the PVP content of the game.

reviewText:
This is a F2P review dated: 02/May/2016

Is this game fun? Yes.

It's not polished, and it is suffering lag (for some screens, such as auction house and mail) due to the influx of the Steam release + new content pack.
Update 06/May/2016: New server upgrade has now fixed the AH/mail lag

There are even some instances where your mid game and the server kicks out, on the plus side through, everything is hosted server side, so you can reconnected to the game where you left off.

Another thing to note, that that not even all the items listed on the original kickstarter are complete.
But, is it fun? Yes!

It's very much like Magic the Gathering, except designed with the digital platform as a goal, not just in mind, but the goal. I would in fact describe this as Magic the Gathering evolved. I'm not surprised there was a, now settled, legal dispute over intellectual property. If you are familiar with the gameplay mechanics of Magic the Gathering, then you can learn the basic of this game in mere minutes.

The F2P section is quite a few hours of content. Well worth the price tag of free.
I'm 40hrs in and still enjoying the first act of the campaign. (I'm playing two playthroughs of the campaign from two opposing sides concurrently).

Give it a try, why not? It's free to try.

PvP/P2P; review yet to be amended to this at a later date. Possibly.
But your better off reading this guys article: http://www.hexprimal.com/an-in-depth-guide-to-hex-from-an-mtg-perspective

reviewText:
So I've been playing this for a while before its Steam release. I've invested a little over 100$ in Constructed decks.

This game is not that hard for people who played card games before. It has very good gameplay and offers a lot of replay value, being similar to MTG in almost every aspect. It has some digital-only card game mechanics that are pretty cool (cards that change other cards or put cards somewhere in the deck, for instance). It's not very hard to learn and you can zoom in on the cards to double-check what they do if you forgot. So that's nice.

The game is not pay2win, it's pay2compete just like other competitive card games. Constructed decks cost a little bit of money but not all that much. Most are between 50 and 100 dollars and you can technically go infinite by grinding. You can also sell your won cards in draft in the auction house to facilitate this.

The playerbase is simply too small for a card game right now. There are days where you sit for over 10 minutes in a (paid) constructed queue waiting for an opponent. You can't leave the queues screen while you wait. To make matters worse, you can face the same opponents multiple times in these queues, making for a generally boring experience. The draft (or Arena" if you come from Hearthstone) is basically the same thing

reviewText:
Been playing since January and loving it.  It's like a better version of Magic the Gathering where they didn't ban the Urza sets and just kept going with the combo themes.  Spider decks will make your hair fall out.

If you've played Magic, you've played something like HEX before.  Not much else to add.  It has a few twists due to being a digital TCG which allows for things you can't do in real life.  NOT like Hearthstone.  The campaign mode is fun and free, getting expanded every few months and will have 3-player raids in the future.

The closest game to this is actually the rather ancient game of Shandalar, a Magic the Gathering solo campaign mode from the dark ages of computer gaming.  Look it up.

Tired of not having people to play card games with at all hours of the day and week?  Then come play here.  Replace your physical cards with digital ones, which still have real world value and can be sold for cash, and come play draft/constructured or PVE with a game not completely revolving around Legendary spam.

reviewText:
F2P? For a while. Then it becomes impossible without spending money. Game mechanics are good, but that's moot as it's impossible to proceed without spending thousands of dollars.

So your three choices are:

1) Play it for free for a while and risk that when it becomes impossible (and it's time to give up) you'll instead spend money you didn't intend and probably a lot more than you'd bargained for.
2) Pay to Play, and pay a lot.
3) Don't play at all.

Note that the difference between commons and rares in this game seems to be MUCH more severe than in Magic: The Gathering. Commons are very poor, so I estimate that it will cost you more than that (at a comparable level of set release), more than it's worth IMO.

reviewText:
I get no resources/resource flood I lose, otherwise I win...summerizes this game.  Further explanation below...

NOTE 1:  I have not reached the max level for all of my adventure zone champions, for the games Player versus Environment (Adventure Zone).  As of this writing 100+ hours of HEX, I feel is enough to do a review for this game.   If anything changes the review will be updated to relfect that, along with the recommendation.

Gameplay References... Think magic the gathering except cards can have equipment.  That is all.

--> Player Versus Environment Content...

PvE content is spread out like an adventure on a big map, you go from point to point battling other AI opponents with your deck.  You are able to customize your deck, with equipment for the cards and with other cards in your library.  The story is written and their is no voice acting and it is very linear.  The battles can have some unique effects, but nothing really stands out as interesting.  There is no branching story options nor and any majorl RPG elements (besides Champions Skills).

A example of a not so thought out chain of events.  The AI opponent in one of the duels (In adventure Zone) after turn 4 starts casting random unique troops.  Usually those tropps are pretty good to incredibly good.  Now along with the chance of getting flooded/ have no resources you have to deal with his random cards.  Luck can work out this way, in the first 5-10 games he can get really good troops, in your duels against this AI.  Now the player is winning based on Luck, not on playing the game well.  That is a really bad game design flaw, losing or winning based on luck of the draw, instead of playing hex well.

Another example is the Gnome Quest.  So your job is to bring back gnomes totaling 60, taking as many trips between 2 sections of the adventure zone with multiple battles.  The gnome cards get put inside your deck and are generally useless.  So the player has to grind many, many battles or hope that he can draw the card he needs without drawing the useless gnomes.  Makes me feel as if I am banging my head against the wall multple times, relying on luck.

This is a good start, but not enough diversity in the PvE mechanics and serious game design flaws.   The nature of the PvE battles you need to buy booster packs, with rares/legends, to do alright later battles in PvE.  Most of the difficult battles at the end end up being luck if you win, making a player feel like a farming gold bot.

There are other duels where you have to draw specific cards to win, which makes repeating the same battles many times.  That is horrible gameplay design theory or feature.

--> PvP Content...

There are drafts, game formats that you can buy into to play against other people.  You can also play in custom matches too.  All of the paying drafts have prizes too, in terms of ingame currency and Booster Packs (16 cards per booster pack).  There is no other game type formats besides 1vs1, would've really liked to see other multiplayer PvP formats.

There are free, one time PvP booster draft every weekend.

--> The Reource system...

Seems like nearly a direct copy of Magic the Gathering.  It is really basic with 5 differemt colors to seperate out the purpose of the 5 different colored non resource cards.

To summerize, boring and nearly a direct copy.

--> Crafting?

Nothing

--> A Wheel of Fortune, Kismet's Slot Machine

You get to use a slot machine to upgrade the chest you get from booster pack with better rewards (Eqiupment, cards, sleeves, mercanaries, etc) or get rewards for just rolling the slot machine.  The currency to roll is Gold, which can be earned by playing Arena or Adventure Zone.  Cool feature

--> The parts that work well...

The auction house in the game works really well.  You can buy PvE and PvP cards and auction your own.  Their are many sorting and filtering options.  The game board is layed out well with as many stops in the gameplay flow as the player wants.  The wheel of Kismet is good too.

--> The Frustrating gameplay mechanic...

In most DTCG the resource system is simplistic. A example of a simplistic system is hearhstone and Ininity Wars,  An example of an expanded resouce system in Faeria, also on steam.

Resouces are mixed into the deck, for HEX.  The recommendation for each deck in HEX to have for resource cards is 40%.  You start the turn taking 7 cards from the top of your deck.  Subsequent turns you draw 1 card per turn form the deck, you draw cards from there are a percentage of games that the player will lose because he does not get enough with his starting digital hand of cards or draws too many resources the beginning, including his cards he drew at the beginning of the games (@ 40% resources)

When you have played a lot of games and you still have the resource system do this to the player a quater of the time (at 40% resources) it gets to be a frustrating experience playing the game.  I cannot recommend spending money on this game to other people for this reason, though it is worth a try, as it is F2P.

I really wish the resource system was not simplistic (not including charges), that is my one major gripe for HEX.  It could have been so much deeper and interesting.  Its the one thing that stopping me from recommending this game, because it gives players a loss or win based upon random luck 1/4 of the time versus playing the game well.

While having 40% resources in a deck, still getting resources floods and starvation some of the time (recent dungeon lost 3 lives to resource disfunction with same opponent, sarcasitcally great gameplay).  I cannot keep my review at recommend this is getting frustrating to be losing by just bad luck, instead of not playing well.  Heathstone, Faeria and other DTCGs have a less disfunctional resource system.  Changing review to Not Recommend...I really wanted this game to Evolve the DTCG instead of bring the frustrations from paper card games.

-->  Last Thoughts...

Recommend try Faeria first , it does more in its gameplay resource mechanics versus HEX just coping most of the resource system from Magic the Gathering.  For me it just doesn't have enough depth in its basic gameplay systems (including resources) for me to spend money on it.  I will continually give it a try though as it is a F2P game, every so often.

Positives
+Has a PvE Element with cards related to it.
+PvE has champions with abilities that level up
+Cards that can have equipment tied to them to improve said cards
+Has Auction System
+Has Chat and email system
+Adventure system (PvE content) gives you free PvE, equipment and PvP cards.

Negatvies
+Simplistic resource system that copies too much from Magic the Gathering trading card game (hasbro).  If you want one that has more in depth system try Faeria.
+PvE adventure is very linear.
+Dungeon system is very linear too and provides little diversity in the PvE content.

What content would change my recommendation to a buy into digital cards/packs?...

Major...
-Resource system not tied to your deck/library.
-Co-Op PvE Comtent
-Finishing the Guild system
-Winning PvP Legendary/PvP cards that are bound to your account through some kind of goal / activity
-More dueling options, customizations (EG restrict Souldbound cards, restrict Set of cards, allow PvE cards, etc)
-Weekly free draft for everyone, rewarded with soul-bnound /account locked cards
-Dyanmic PvE world which you can affect that is not so linear.

Minor...
-Teams of Player vs Player game modes
-A Risk like map where you control multiple decks.

MISC
Guild/Clan Community system (Community Feature) has yet to arrive into the game.  See kickstarter HEX.  Also for people that say seperating the resources into a seperate draw pile (EG draw 1 resource per turn) to draw from, it doesn't stop the players from making the same decks they could at any other time.

reviewText:
The game's free-to-play so go ahead and give it a try if you want to. It's quite entertaining. I can't completely recommend it though.

I started a game, played through the tutorial, made myself a spider cleric champion, made a control deck, played through spider intro quests, adventured and then got into my first real dungeon. The boss slaughtered me completely. My deck isn't able to clear the dungeon - I'm facing a powerful aggro deck against which my unreliable and slow control deck can't win against. If I want to win, I either have to create a new hero or spend money on new cards.

I feel like that's going to be a vicious cycle in games like these. If you want to keep winning, you have to keep spending money on new cards. My excitement to play this game died with that realization.

Also, this card game incorporated the worst card game element from Magic the Gathering: the system in which you have to draw resource cards from your deck in order to do anything. Not drawing any resources? Tough luck, try again. Yu-Gi-Oh, Duel Masters and Hearthstone all have a far superior system to this.

reviewText:
Essentially unplayable on OS X

I can understand the server issues when the game was launched on Steam. I can get some of the bugs from time to time - certain effects not being applied, certain issues with menus or the auction house. But what drives me mad is that the Campaign - which seems to be extremely important to the core of the game - is so fraught with crashes and freezing that the game is unplayable.

I'm virtually guaranteed to have the game lock up on the LOADING screen whenever a duel is completed. That's when I'm lucky. Frequently the game locks up during the duel, or when I'm simpy attempting to view my deck - requiring the game be force closed and restarted, and occasionally requiring my entire system to reboot.

There isn't a single part of this software that isn't crawling with bugs - the login fails, the mail system in inaccessible, servers lag painfully, the combat itself doesn't work correctly, rules don't matter because half the time they aren't applied, and everything. always. freezes.

I'll admit it - I shelled out some $ for cards too - I wish I could use them regularly. I keep being told to be patient, but it really looks like none of these major issues are going to be resolved anytime soon.

I'd suggest you take your time, and definitely take your money, elsewhere.

reviewText:
Pay to win PvP. Not surprising, but still a point against it.

Artificially difficult PvE. Why bother putting together intelligent AI and smart decks for the single player campaign when you can just give the AI a huge boost or the player a huge handicap? Often the PvE seems to boil down to whether or not you draw your best cards on curve and whether or not the AI does something really stupid. Otherwise it seems as if you need only the most broken cards in your deck and/or to grind character levels like a JRPG to get anywhere.

Nice digital MtG clone with cool mechanics that would be impossible, or at least awkward as hell to implement with physical cards. Could have been spectacular, but what seems like fairly lazy methods of creating difficulty in PvE really ticked me off a few times too many. Play it if you have money to burn and like Magic or if you like bending over in PvE and saying please AI

reviewText:
I wish there was a way to give a dead average review with no thumbs up or down.

I installed this game on a brand new MacBook Pro, and from the offset there were problems. On the first opening, the game chose a resolution that was the wrong size and left about half of the screen off the game. Since you can't navigate the settings without the mouse, I had to use the mouse to click buttons that weren't actually in the right spot due to resolution issues. Setting the game to the appropriate resolution took nearly 30 minutes of tinkering. Honestly? Your game should be able to detect this and set itself.

And then I played for about an hour. It's a really fun game that has cribbed basically everything it does from Magic: The Gathering. I'm not really mad at that, but it does. Some things it gets wrong, though. Normally, in Magic, you can use the activated abilities of cards at any time. In Hex, you can only use them during your first main phase or not at all. Honestly, they should just change this and make it more similar, rather than 'inspired by, but worse.'

The plot, as it was for the hour I played, was interesting. Good villains, Aztec orcs, etc. Pretty cool.

I tried to log on again today, and the game had the wrong resolution again, but this time it was too small. 3/4 of my screen was white, and the game took up only the portion in the lower 1/4 of the screen. However, now any time I try to change the Settings, the game freezes. It's irritating, and while the game is fun, it's not fun enough to actually go through the effort of fixing their terrible coding.

It's too bad, really. This was a fun game. I really enjoyed it, and could've seen spending some cash to buy a few cool packs. The problem is that getting  hosed like that for bad coding and then not even having the settings be accessible just killed it for me.
Oh, an additional thing: Wizards are just straight up better, at least at the beginning levels. For some reason, warriors start out with one less card in exchange for an ability of dubious usefullness. Mages and clerics get an extra card, and mages get an extra spell on top of that. They're just straight up better, which kind of sucks in a game that should be about balance and playing cleverly.

reviewText:
Regretably I cant reccomend HEX.

It actually does everything and I mean everything way better than MTG and tons more that MTG wanted to do, but never did.

However, it suffers the same resources issues that most CCG's suffer from. Each game you play, wether its verses human or AI can essentially be categorised into 3 types of game

1. You suffer resource flood/drought so you'll lose.  Not enjoyable.
2. Your opponent suffers, and you win.  Not enjoyable.. victory over someone who is flooded is a sucky game
3.  Either you both suffer or neither of you suffer = good game!

Essentially it means that about 65% of your games are not going to be fun or enjoyable, they are going to be annoying because they have nothing to do with your ability or your deck build.

To be clear, when I win against an opponent who lost only because of resource issues is NOT FUN.  great you won a game.. but it had nothing to do with you.

Hearthstone is the only CCG that resolves this issue... and oh look, its the biggest most popular card game in history. No, I've never played Hearthstone, but highlights my point about all ccg's that follow this exact same resource system where you essentially rely on random luck.

Sure, if you dont mind that fact that most of your games are not actually going to be fun to play you'd love hex.. or any ccg,  but I for one dont.    I dont like that the fact that result of my game, win or lose, has nothing to do with my ability or my deck... most of the time.

reviewText: If you want to play Magic: The Gathering with different cards, this is your game.  The game copies the ruleset of Magic: The Gathering to the letter, just changes the words for certain things (Sorceries become Basic Actions, Instants become Quick Actions, Enchantments are Constants, Artifacts are... still Artifacts, actually).  The upside to this is that if you already know how to play Magic, you know how to play Hex.  The downside is that mana screw/flood is still an issue.  However, Hex does have character abilities (like Vanguard in M:TG) and skill trees that may help (I lost interest too soon to find out; mana screw was one of the main reasons I quit playing Magic).  So, there's a little more depth than Magic, but it's basically the same game.\n\nAt least it doesn't have completely random effects like Hearthstone.  That game is so good until someone plays one of many random effects and then it becomes Flip a coin to see who wins."  At least mana screw doesn't let you have the illusion of winning."

reviewText:
The rules system of the game is mostly just a copy of Magic: The Gathering. The parts that are not are terrible randomized effects, that removes quite a bit of strategy from the game and makes it all about grinding until you get the roll needed. The blatant copying of MtG is ridiculous as well, even the colors play out almost identical as their MtG counterpart. There are a lot of different rule systems out there, and they work pretty well, so I can only consider this as lazyness or intentional stealing of another system. Sure, other games have similar card effects as MtG, because there's only a finite number of non-stupid card effects, but with different core ruleset the games play out quite differently.

On the positive side, dungeons and adventures are nice, graphics is good, music is not remarkable but not terrible either.

But the main reason I'm deleting this game and never touch it again is because the loads of bugs in it. And not just small glitches: card effects not triggering, complete UI freezing, buttons being unclickable for no reason, auction house is so badly designed, it's ridiculous, and sometimes the game just skipped some phases of my turn, so f*** planning.

If you steal something, at least make something good out of it. This game is no good. I'm happy I didn't have to pay for it.

reviewText:
Hex COULD be a really good game, but instead it's just a really frustrating RNG exercise.

Huge flaw in the core mechanic of the game is that the resources that you need to play cards...are also cards!

You stack your deck with different types of gems, which you need to have enter your hand (via drawing a card once per turn) so that you can play them in order to unlock a threshold that allows you to play other cards.  So let's say a sapphire card requires that you have 2 sapphires unlocked, but you keep drawing every other type of gem - or you don't draw any gem cards and just draw combat cards.

Vice versa you keep drawing gem cards and can't draw any combat cards.  You'll just sit there and watch your hero quickly killed while you can't do anything about it.  So you'll enter the deck builder and increase the number of gem cards that are in your deck, therefore increasing the likelyhood that you can draw some gems, which will allow you to play combat cards.  Then you'll start drawing nothing but gem cards and have no combat cards in your hand with which to attack or defend.  Or the combat cards you can draw require more gems than you can draw. You could literally be killed by a single 1/1 card hitting you down to 0 health because you can't play anything.

Basically this game requires your RNG to grant you the perfect mix of resource cards and combat cards, which is very unique (see: flawed and stupid).  There's a reason that most other card games don't do this - IT DOESN'T WORK.

Great artwork, neat campaign and story, cards feel reasonably balanced, you can tell a lot of work and care went into making this game, but it's fatally flawed.

3/10.  Oops, let's draw again: 7/10.  Nope, that's not it, draw again 5/10. 10/10? 6/10? 2/10 5/10 2/10 4/10, ah, there we go! 4/10.

reviewText:
Lame Magic the Gathering ripoff, without the design chops that make Magic fun. There are so many TCGs out there that are actually creative, and bring something new to the table, often for much less money than HEX demands you spend.

Basically, if you have the money and you're looking for a deep, strategic experience, Magic is still your best bet. If you're looking for something cheaper or more accessible, there's Hearthstone, Spellweaver, SolForge, Card Hunter... and a ton more I'm probably forgetting. By slavishly copying Magic's mechanics without having Magic's design team to back it up, Hex fails at both strategic depth and accessibility.

I'm a huge fan of TCGs, and have played many of them. There's really no reason to play Hex unless you're one of the suckers who Kickstarted it for the ridiculously OP kickstarter bonuses.

(I tried Hex before it came to Steam, and only installed it here to write this review, hence the minimal playtime.)

reviewText: Take Magic: The Gathering, wait for patents to run out, and slap a thin veneer of new features on it without changing core gameplay at all (turn structure: identical, card types map exactly to Magic card types, etc.) and don't bother with quality art, and you have HEX: the least original CCG I've seen in two decades of trying them.  I've been disgusted by tons of games for tons of reasons, but this is the first time I've ever been sincerely disgusted by such severe copying of concepts.  Too little is changed in the way of core functionality to even consider it a matter of inspiration or homage; this is a clone in the most derogatory sense of the word.\n\nThere are two legitimate reasons to play: It's what your friends are playing, or you're turned off by Wizards' awful recent online offerings (which would be understandable; Magic Duels is lousy, and Magic Online is so dated it hurts).  If those aren't the case, flip a coin.  Heads: 20 years of development of mechanics and card base.  Tails: A few benefits of being digital only (persistant buffs, etc.).  Either way, you're playing the same game.

reviewText:
Do NOT let any of the glowing reviews fool you. This game is STRICTLY P2W. Oh, they try to lure you in, lul your suspicions by having an intersting class system and the first 15 or so battles be easy. But then you learn by battle 10 there is no strategy. Combos only exist as a side note to the main point. Rush.

Agro rush. There is no other point to this game. Chuck your strategy book out the window, this is a game of raw math. Do I have bigger numbers than my opponet.

And when I say P2W I am not kidding. Once you start seeing how ungodly powerful rare and above cards are compared to what you can normally get? Yea. If you dont have rare or better cards you may as well just ram your head into a wall for a good 20 minutes, it will be more rewarding. At least youll have a concussion and wont feel insulted for wasting your time.

TL:DR : Game claims to be a MtG clone + extra. Is really P2W worse than MtG, almost 3x over. Do not waste your time.

reviewText:
TL:DR: Flawed concept, clunky UI, obsolete mana draw mechanics, almost non existent PVE content and zero MMO features othen than Auction  house. This MTG sued wannabe clone shoulda learned something during their 2 year beta before coming to steam. Check the positive reviews, most of those are writen by Hex white knights, game is nothing like its being described.
Go play Duelyst or android TCG and save yourself some time

Why not recommened, well  for starters it doesnt add anything new, a sued clone of MTG, you either win or lose  based on  an obsolete mechanic: mana draw. You either get enough mana cards or you dont, plain and simple.

Then you have the P2W aspect, to be able to participate on PVP you either farm PVE at a snail pace just to buy some packs or you get your wallet up and make yourself the best P2W deck posible. You will have the white knights of this game  cutting their wrist defending this aspect, in their  peasant minds this is what make hex unique, a mmo TCG, being able to buy every card with money, you can buy cards with pve currency which is gold but its garbage cards that you can get by playing yourself and most of them are only good for PVE, so you play PVE to get a PVE deck and grind gold to be able to paly PVP in a month from now if you have a life, or you get your wallet buy platinum and start PVP today.

Will the mana draw mechanic be changed?, most likely not and with that decision this game  will soon be forgotten like spellweaver and any game that in 2016 decides  mana draw is still a thing.

Then comes the small PVE campaign,  i think max lv for the campaign is 8 or 9, that lv you can get it in a single day if you are a grinder, am lv 7 and been playing on and off for 2 weeks doing the fight nodes slowly since there is nothing else once you complete other than creating a new hero and repeat so in a single day you see everything the games has to offer and then you just grind gold to transform it to platinum( premiun currency used for everything PVP related) and try PVP.

Playersbase was really small for what i saw, in the 2 week i been on and off, its the same 10 or so  guys chatting online usually a newbie like me asking PVE questions related, again the white knight will say this isnt so the game is a WOW killer blablabla, i dont think the total playerbase is over 1k a lot of people complained on the HEX forums about  long PVP queues and when they do they had to fight the same guy over and over because there wasnt anyone else on queue
Will this be fixed by being on steam: No
In order to create a stable playerbase the game needs a stronger PVE component which all the white knights dont want they want more  PVP  features but those mentally challenged few dont understand is that the game without PVE has zero draw to keep a players more than  a single day once they  check the lacking PVE.

Then you have the game that is run by Gameforge, a company that is known to drain games of their life and then toss their husks once they stop making money.

reviewText:
note:
i currently have complete collections for mtg, mtgo, cardhunter, dyelist, hs, netrunner, game of thrones lcg, warhammer lcg, dice masters, doomtown, and more i probably don't even remember.

Another day, another tcg trying to cash in on hearthstone/mtg craze.

So what do we have here... 100$ for 9k plat, the cheapest budget pvp decks i could find cost 5k plat with the mojority being 15k+ all the way up to 35k. I mean makes sense. Visiting the Auction House, filtering by legendary and just browsing thru cards starting with A I found a few that cost 2000p per and they seemed pretty good. There was an angel that costs 4 but the turn you draw it costs 0 to cast so yea 8000p for a playset.

I couldn't find booster packs buyable with in-game currency nor were any of the legendaries available in the AH buyable with gold so yea. There is some spinning thing but I don't have the patience to learn how it works but given the things I already listed I sincerely doubt you will be getting that sweet sweet angel anytime soon without real moolah.

What those mtg/hs wanna bes don't get is that both of those games have inherent value that have been developed for a while. Those dudes just want to come in half cocked and charge same or more as them. Those companies have invested quite a lot to get to the point where they can sell crap at such prices. Plus you can be pretty sure that they will both be around for a long time.

Now if you have not invested in either hex is probably deeper and better than hs but not mtg. For free play I doubt you can be at all competitive in this game and lets face it: who the heck wants to play a tcg against a dumb AI to grind worthless gold they cannot get the real sweet card with, let alone a playset.

To the developers: I suggest you drastically lower your prices and free to play structure until you have a good enough base that you can start increasing your prices as your expirience starts increasing because you are not magic's R&D that has been doing this crap for 22 years and have balancing and interactivity down to an art. Or maybe try the whole LCG thing and be at least a bit innovative in the field.

p.s. i am very rich, i have everything for both paper and mtgo, full all gold collection on hs, full collection on dyelist (which i actually will recommend way way over this pile) and whatever else. I spend at least 2k/month on games alone, and that is when there is nothing new. I am saying this so you understand I can go in right now and buy it all, even at those prices, but I am just sick and tired of companies coming in and trying this crap. I mean I waste my money but not like this.

p.s.s. also for 350$ bucks you can buy a pretty high end magic online deck and at least have some real fun + play in tournaments and leagues where you can make real money and when you get tired you can sell that deck, take a small hit and go play something else. And sometimes you might even make more money than you spent if your deck became more popular. for instance back in the day when liliana of the veil was released I bought a playset for 30$ a piece and then when they rotated out of standard sold them for 150$ a piece... so yea like that.

reviewText:
After a very frustrating steam rollout it seems that the game is finally playable once again.

This is a skill based long-term strategy minded game very similar to Magic the Gathering or Hearthstone, but with added PVE and virtual elements that those other games do not have.

Hex is designed to appeal to all levels of players from casual novice to hardcore pro level players. The game has two engaging PVE formats that can be replayed almost an infinite number of times to gain new cards, gold, platinum, etc. For the more competitive players the game has several PVP formats that let you match up against other players in familiar tourney types such as draft, constructed, and gauntlet.

The long-term plan is where Hex really shines.  At the current rate of content rollout it may take a few years before Hex has all of the features that they promised players but that ensures a long and hopefully healthy life for this game. The cards in the game have real money value and some gamers do play this game to make real cash from tournaments or sale of in-game items. The rollout of new PVE and PVP content over the next few years will likely continue to increase the value of the cards so that any players getting into Hex now should be able to cash out" later for a nice payday. The game requires no money to play and is not Pay2win since you can get all of the cards by simply grinding out games against the AI many times. For those people who prefer to buy the cards with real money that option is available and saves a lot of time but doesn't make you a better player. In short
date: skill is rewarded in this game."

4/25/16 edit:
I suppose I'll do a proper review, since I completely judged from a brief, 8 hour, first impression.
I'm pretty sure I'm just being salty, since I ragequit and tossed the game from my library, but I guess I'll give it another shot. I don't really play TCG, so I can only give the perspective of a total noob, which is the main reason I didn't recommend it.

For a game that is able to be free thanks to the whole Kickstarter campaign, it's certainly worth giving a shot. No complaints in terms of the graphics, or the artwork. My lower-end laptop runs the game perfectly fine. It kinda saddened me that the extended artwork on the cards was literally just the whole card picture without the info on it, but the detail is still good.

This game doesn't serve anything up on a silver platter, so everyone who's used to winning everything at the start is going to get a rude awakening much like I did. I suppose that would make for much more exciting gameplay, since players can't just breeze through high-level matches with OP cards later on, but... still. tl;dr it's all about the heart of the cards and the luck of the draw.

reviewText:
It's a pay-to-win game but there is a free campaign that makes up for the major negative. There are 2 kinds of currency in the game, Gold and Platinum. Platinum is the cash shop currency while Gold is the in-game currency which you can earn from completing quests. The best exchange rate I saw was $150 for 9000 Platinum (40 Platinum per $1), each booster pack costs 200 Platinum. You can basically get 45 packs for $150.

After playing the game, I would recommend the campaign but not the multiplayer as that would be a money drain. The campaign is honestly very good but you only need to complete it with 1 race as it's the same trail with all the others. You just want to create new champions to get the rare cards.

PROS
1. Interesting Storyline/World
Basically divided into a centuries long battle between light and dark, with the Ardent as the light and the Underworld as the dark. A long time ago, a meteorite crashed onto the planet creating magical shards and everyone called it Hex. The meteorite also brought along some undead called the Necrotic. The Necrotic was attacked by the Human, Elves, Coyotyl

2. Hero Powers / Charges
There is a way to play even if your hand is full of mana-producing gems called Charges. Once you get enough charges, you can use a hero power to change the gameplay. There are usually a couple to choose from.

3. Interesting Races
8 in total
Ardent - Human, Elf, Orc, Coyotl (coyotes)
Underworld - Necrotic, Dwarf, Shinhare (bunnies), Vennen (spiders)

The standard Tolkien fare of Human, Elf, Orc, Dwarf and Undead have been used and re-used so many times that it's a given cliche. It is pretty interesting to see the Coyotyl which are based on Native American tribalism, Shinhare based on Japanese Imperial rule and Vennen based on an insect Hive.

4. Classes
3 main classes :
a. Cleric : Pray, Shard Attuned, <Racial Talent>
b. Warrior : Battle, Shard Attuned, <Racial Talent>
c. Mage : Replenish Spell Power, Learn Spell Soothsaying, <Racial Talent>

I expect Warlock, Rogue and Ranger classes to appear in the future.

All races have access to the same classes. What I like about the variety is that while the basic skills are the same, the racial talent will vary depending on what race you picked. There are also Race-Class Combos which pair up with the Racial Talent ensuring that different heroes can change how a deck is played. I am expecting more classes in the future which will probably follow the standard World of Warcraft model.

5. Campaign
The campaign is pretty impressive. This is the one thing that I would recommend to people. There is a narrative and a proper game with a leveling up system. It's a pity for the ridiculous exchange rates.

6. Abilities that will be a Hassle in a Physical Card Game
a. 2 random troop cards in your deck get +1/+1, next troop in your deck gets +1/+1

To be totally fair with physical cards, you would need a 3rd party to randomly search through all the troop cards and do the above by placing markers on the card. If you do it yourself or get your opponent to do it, there might be cases of cheating or information given away.

b. Summon a Random Creature

You can't do that with physical cards. You would need a list, a proxy card and list of random creatures to randomise with.

c. Socketing

You would have have to prepare a marker in the card to show it's additional unique ability.

CONS
1. Pay To Win
This is really hardcore pay to win. You can't even grind to catchup. The 200 Platinum required for a pack is ridiculous. That averages out to $5 per booster pack minimum. It usually costs more.

2. Ridiculous Grinding / Exchange Rate
You need approximately 20,000 gold to trade for 1 booster pack. You earn 200 gold per battle in the campaign. You need 100 battles just to bid for the 1 booster pack.

3. Random Number Generator
Can one complain about how similar the mulligan rule is to Magic the Gathering and how it forces you to mulligan your whole hand? It would have been better if you could keep some cards and mulligan the rest, similar to Hearthstone.

4. Auction House
The search filters are extremely bad. You will see multiple copies of the same card for many pages and you are unable to skip ahead. The load times between page refreshes are also extremely long. This ensures that players only get to see cards that start with the letter A.

5. No Heroes directly affecting the field
Sure, there are charges for hero abilities but the hero can't do anything without charges. E.g. Attack a Minion directly

6. Auto Full-Healing of Troops
Still a major problem. This makes +1 HP way too valuable as all you need to do is survive the engagement.

7. No Targetting of Blockers
You can't choose who to attack, only the blockers get to choose.

8. Mana-Screwed
Too many or too few. You die either way.

NEUTRAL
1. Gem Socketing
Interesting to note but there is a slight negative in the idea that you have to get a specific gem to socket it rather than choosing a variation of the card. I think Hearthstone has the same idea.

SUGGESTIONS
1. Gender Discrepancy
This is sure to create controversy and attract attention to the game. Make the females have a different variation of racial talents from their male counterparts and let the players decide which is stronger.

2. Auction House
Advanced search parameters to remove cards that have a certain keyword from the search. E.g. -Abominate"

reviewText:
Somewhat clunky Magic the Gathering clone with an engaging pve campaign.

After my initial impressions were marred by crashes and server errors, I grudgingly pushed further into the game and kept finding myself coming back for more.

The core gameplay borrows heavily from MtG, and as such is fun. The pve campaign is very good, and adds some interesting features (gear, a skill tree). PvP is not very casual friendly though, and card acquisition is a bit stingier than other digital card games, with few freebies and an emphasis on player trading.

Recommended for anyone interested in a free pve card game, as well as big spenders or hardcore grinders looking for a pvp alternative to MtG.

reviewText:
TL;DR AVAILABLE AT THE BOTTOM

Pros:
+The game is way more complex than Hearthstone (which was too simplistic for my taste)
+The tactics you can execute in this game can be ridiculously convoluted and it's glorious
+The combination of possible decks are basically endless. There are very little restrictions.
+The PvE/Campaign of this game can is brutal but rewarding
+So many different styles of gameplay
+PvE (Brutal and completely unfair at early stages)
+Create your own customizable character for the campaign
+Very engaging competitive play
+Admins/Developers are available everyday. They are actively in the game's global chat every single day.

Cons:
-PvP packs can only be purchased through premium currency (But can be bought from players with PvE currency)
-PvE Campaign is not beginner friendly. Some missions require a specifically built counter-deck
-Slow development on PvE content
-Beginner f2p players will be utterly destroyed in PvP until they can build their collection up
-Personally, I dislike the resource system where the resources used are also cards that must be accounted for during deck construction and drawn. You can lose a game right at the mulligan if your luck is that bad and/or if the resource to non-resource ratio in your deck is unbalanced.

Neutral:
>Grind heavy for currency and character exp
>Games are around 15-40 minutes
>Princess Cory (The boss fight)
>There is a fair amount of RNG applied to some cards. The RNG is absolutely insane. You can spend 1 resource to summon a god or 10 resources to summon a cardboard box.

Overall:
If you're looking for a card game with complexity and insane 40 minute battles between 200 troops, this is the game for you. I'm not even exaggerating, I actually had matches where each side of the field was around 100 troops each. If you have the patience to grind out gold to buy cards and learn the mechanics of....everything, then I highly recommend this game. You don't have to pay any real cash to make progress, but it makes it easier. With an ever changing meta and a constant stream of new deck concepts, the scene and the market are always changing.

TL;DR:
*Play if you like complex card games with ridiculously convoluted mechanics both PvP and PvE.
*Not beginner friendly and premium currency is a luxury, not a necessity. Premium currency can be obtained through the game's market for non-premium currency.
